revision.text:
In [[psychiatry]], '''complicated grief disorder''' (CGD) is a proposed disorder for those who are significantly and functionally impaired by [[Prolonged Grief Disorder|prolonged grief]] symptoms for at least one month after six months of [[Grief|bereavement]].<ref name="one">{{cite journal|last1=Shear|first1=MK|last2=Simon|first2=N|last3=Wall|first3=M|last4=Zisook|first4=S|last5=Neimeyer|first5=R|last6=Duan|first6=N|last7=Reynolds|first7=C|last8=Lebowitz|first8=B|last9=Sung|first9=S|last10=Ghesquiere|first10=A|last11=Gorscak|first11=B|last12=Clayton|first12=P|last13=Ito|first13=M|last14=Nakajima|first14=S|last15=Konishi|first15=T|last16=Melhem|first16=N|last17=Meert|first17=K|last18=Schiff|first18=M|last19=O'Connor|first19=MF|last20=First|first20=M|last21=Sareen|first21=J|last22=Bolton|first22=J|last23=Skritskaya|first23=N|last24=Mancini|first24=AD|last25=Keshaviah|first25=A|title=Complicated grief and related bereavement issues for DSM-5.|journal=Depression and Anxiety|date=February 2011|volume=28|issue=2|pages=103–17|doi=10.1002/da.20780|pmid=21284063|pmc=3075805}}</ref> It is distinguished from non-impairing grief<ref name="two">O’Connor MF, Wellisch DK, Stanton AL, et al. Craving love? Enduring grief activates brain’s reward center. Neuroimage 2008;42:969–972.</ref> and other disorders (such as [[major depressive disorder]]<ref name="three">Silverman GK, Jacobs SC, Kasl SV, et al. Quality of life impairments associated with diagnostic criteria for traumatic grief. Psychol Med 2000;30:857–862.</ref><ref name="four">Simon NM, Shear KM, Thompson EH, et al. The prevalence and correlates of psychiatric comorbidity in individuals with complicated grief. Compr Psychiatry 2007;48:395–399.</ref><ref name="five">Neria Y, Gross R, Litz B, et al. Prevalence and psychological correlates of complicated grief among bereaved adults 2.5–3.5 years after september 11th attacks. J Trauma Stress 2007;20:251–262.</ref><ref name="six">Melhem NM, Rosales C, Karageorge J, et al. Comorbidity of axis i disorders in patients with traumatic grief. J Clin Psychiatry 2001;62:884–887.</ref><ref name="seven">Kersting A, Kroker K, Horstmann J, et al. Association of mao-a variant with complicated grief in major depression. Neuropsychobiology 2007;56:191–196.</ref><ref name="eight">Viederman M. Grief: normal and pathological variants. Am J Psychiatry 1995;152:1–4.</ref> and [[posttraumatic stress disorder]]).<ref name="four" /><ref name="five" /><ref name="six" /><ref name="nine">Melhem NM, Moritz G, Walker M, et al. Phenomenology and correlates of complicated grief in children and adolescents. J Am Acad Child Adolesc Psychiatry 2007;46:493–499.</ref><ref name="ten">Bonanno GA, Neria Y, Mancini A, et al. Is there more to complicated grief than depression and posttraumatic stress disorder? A test of incremental validity. J Abnorm Psychol 2007; 116:342–351.</ref> This disorder has been reviewed by the [[DSM-5]] work groups, who have decided that it be called '''Persistent complex bereavement disorder''' and placed it in the chapter on Conditions for Further Study in the new [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-5]].<ref name="eleven">[http://www.dsm5.org/proposedrevision/Pages/Conditions-Proposed-by-Outside-Sources.aspx Conditions Proposed by Outside Sources | APA DSM-5<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Description == Complicated [[grief]] is considered when an individual’s ability to resume normal activities and responsibilities is continually disrupted beyond six months of bereavement. Six months is considered to be the appropriate point of CGD consideration, since studies show that most people are able to integrate bereavement into their lives by this time.<ref name="twelve">Bonanno GA, Wortman CB, Lehman DR, et al. Resilience to loss and chronic grief: a prospective study from preloss to 18-months postloss. J Pers Soc Psychol 2002;83:1150–1164.</ref><ref name="thirteen">DeVaul RA, Zisook S. Psychiatry: unresolved grief. Clinical considerations. J Postgrad Med 1976;59:267–271.</ref><ref name="fourteen">DeVaul RA, Zisook S, Faschingbauer TR. Clinical aspects of grief and bereavement. Prim Care 1979;6:391–402.</ref><ref name="fifteen">Zisook S, Shuchter S, Schuckit M. Factors in the persistence of unresolved grief among psychiatric outpatients. Psychosomatics 1985;26:497–503.</ref><ref name="sixteen">Dopson CC, Harper MB. Unresolved grief in the family. Am Fam Physician 1983;27:207–211.</ref>
=== Symptoms === The symptoms of complicated grief are mentioned in the most-recently proposed diagnostic criteria; they include maladaptive thoughts and behaviors related to the death or the deceased, continuous emotional dysregulation about the death, social isolation and [[suicidal ideation]].<ref name="one" />
=== Causes and predictors === Although more research is needed to determine the multiple pathways to complicated grief disorder, preexisting conditions (such as major depression, PTSD, and [[sleep disorders]]) are thought to exacerbate the interruption of the natural healing process.<ref name="one" />
There are some known predictive characteristics for CGD.<ref name="one" /> An individual is at increased risk for CGD if they are: * Female<ref name="five" /><ref name="seventeen">Shear MK, Jackson CT, Essock SM, et al. Screening for complicated grief among project liberty service recipients 18 months after september 11, 2001. Psychiatr Serv 2006;57: 1291–1297.</ref> * [[Pessimism|Pessimistic]]<ref name="eighteen">Piper WE, McCallum M, Joyce AS, et al. Patient personality and time-limited group psychotherapy for complicated grief. Int J Group Psychother 2001;51:525–552.</ref><ref name="nineteen">Robinson T, Marwit SJ. An investigation of the relationship of personality, coping, and grief intensity among bereaved mothers. Death Stud 2006;30:677–696.</ref> * Previously diagnosed with a [[mood disorder]]<ref name="four" /><ref name="six" /> * Low self-reported social support<ref name="twenty">Ott CH. The impact of complicated grief on mental and physical health at various points in the bereavement process. Death Stud 2003;27:249–272.</ref> * An insecure [[Attachment theory#Attachment patterns|attachment]]<ref name="twentyone">Johnson JG, Zhang B, Greer JA, PrigersonHG. Parental control, partner dependency, and complicated grief among widowed adults in the community. J Nerv Ment Dis 2007;195:26–30.</ref><ref name="twentytwo">Vanderwerker LC, Jacobs SC, Parkes CM, Prigerson HG. An exploration of associations between separation anxiety in childhood and complicated grief in later life. J Nerv Ment Dis 2006;194:121–123.</ref><ref name="twentythree">Prigerson HG, Shear MK, Bierhals AJ, et al. Case histories of traumatic grief. Omega 1997;35:9–24.</ref><ref name="twentyfour">Prigerson HG, Shear MK, Frank E, et al. Traumatic grief: a case of loss-induced trauma. Am J Psychiatry 1997;154:1003–1009.</ref><ref name="twentyfive">Van Doorn C, Kasl SV, Beery LC, et al. The influence of marital quality and attachment styles on traumatic grief and depressive symptoms. J Nerv Ment Dis 1998;186:566–573.</ref> * High [[Stress (psychological)|stress]]<ref name="twenty" /> * A positive caregiving experience and dependency on the deceased<ref name="twentysix">Chiu YW, Huang CT, Yin SM, Huang YC, Chien CH, Chuang HY. Determinants of complicated grief in caregivers who cared for terminal cancer patients. Support Care Cancer 2010;18:1321–1327.</ref><ref name="twentyeight">Schulz R, Boerner K, Shear K, et al. Predictors of complicated grief among dementia caregivers: a prospective study of bereavement. Am J Geriatr Psychiatry 2006;14:650–658.</ref><ref name="twentynine">Boerner K, Schulz R, Horowitz A. Positive aspects of caregiving and adaptation to bereavement. Psychol Aging 2004;19:668–675.</ref> * Have had an early [[Miscarriage and mental illness|pregnancy loss]] ([[Miscarriage and grief|miscarriage]])<ref name = kirs>{{Cite journal|last=Kersting|first=Anette|last2=Wagner|first2=Birgit|date=June 2012|title=Complicated grief after perinatal loss|journal=Dialogues in Clinical Neuroscience|volume=14|issue=2|pages=187–194|issn=1294-8322|pmc=3384447|pmid=22754291}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2012/06/miscarriage.aspx|title=Miscarriage and loss|publisher = American Psychological Association | date = 2017 |access-date=2017-09-23}}</ref>
=== Consequences === Untreated CGD has clinically significant consequences. A high level of impairment can be pervasive,<ref name="three"/><ref name="four" /><ref name="six" /><ref name="ten" /><ref name="seventeen" /><ref name="thirty">Prigerson HG, Bierhals AJ, Kasl SV, et al. Traumatic grief as a risk factor for mental and physical morbidity. Am J Psychiatry 1997;154:616–623.</ref><ref name="thirtyone">Chen JH, Bierhals AJ, Prigerson HG, et al. Gender differences in the effects of bereavement-related psychological distress in health outcomes. Psychol Med 1999;29:367–380.</ref><ref name="thirtytwo">Boelen PA, Prigerson HG. The influence of symptoms of prolonged grief disorder, depression, and anxiety on quality of life among bereaved adults: a prospective study. Eur Arch Psychiatry Clin Neurosci 2007;257:444–452.</ref><ref name="thirtythree">Ott CH, Lueger RJ, Kelber ST, Prigerson HG. Spousal bereavement in older adults: common, resilient, and chronic grief with defining characteristics. J Nerv Ment Dis 2007;195: 332–341.</ref><ref name="thirtyfour">Lannen PK, Wolfe J, Prigerson HG, et al. Unresolved grief in a national sample of bereaved parents: impaired mental and physical health 4 to 9 years later. J Clin Oncol 2008;26:5870–5876.</ref><ref name="thirtysix">Shear K, Monk T, Houck P, et al. An attachment-based model of complicated grief including the role of avoidance. Eur Arch Psychiatry Clin Neurosci 2007;257: 453–461.</ref><ref name="thirtyseven">Cruz M, Scott J, Houck P, et al. Clinical presentation and treatment outcome of african americans with complicated grief. Psychiatr Serv 2007;58:700–702.</ref><ref name="thirtyeight">Zuckoff A, Shear K, Frank E, et al. Treating complicated grief and substance use disorders: a pilot study. J Subst Abuse Treat 2006;30:205–211.</ref> including destructive thoughts and behaviors (such as [[substance abuse]]).<ref name="sixteen" /><ref name="thirtynine">Hardison HG, Neimeyer RA, Lichstein KL. Insomnia and complicated grief symptoms in bereaved college students. Behav Sleep Med 2005;3:99–111.</ref> CGD may worsen the course of preexisting disorders and contribute to the development of new ones.<ref name="thirtyfive">Simon NM, Pollack MH, Fischmann D, et al. Complicated grief and its correlates in patients with bipolar disorder. J Clin Psychiatry 2005;66:1105–1110.</ref><ref name="forty">Maytal G, Zalta AK, Thompson E, et al. Complicated grief and impaired sleep in patients with bipolar disorder. Bipolar Disord 2007;9:913–917.</ref>
== Proposed diagnostic criteria == According to Shear et al. (2011):<ref name="one" /> *The person has been bereaved (i.e. experienced the death of a loved one) for at least six months *At least one of the following symptoms of persistent, intense, acute grief has been present for a period longer than is expected by others in the person’s social (or cultural) environment: **Persistent intense yearning or longing for the person who died **Frequent intense feelings of loneliness, or that life is empty or meaningless without the person who died **Recurrent thoughts that it is unfair, meaningless or unbearable to live when a loved one has died, or a recurrent urge to die in order to find (or join) the deceased **Frequent preoccupying thoughts about the person who died; e.g. thoughts or images of the person intrude on activities or interfere with functioning *At least two of the following symptoms are present for at least one month: **Frequent, troubling rumination about the circumstances (or consequences) of the death (concerns about how or why the person died, about not being able to manage without their loved one, thoughts of having let the deceased person down, etc.) **Recurrent feeling of disbelief or inability to accept the death **Persistent feeling of shock; feeling stunned, dazed or emotionally numb since the death **Recurrent feelings of anger or bitterness related to the death **Persistent difficulty trusting or caring about other people, or envy of others who have not experienced a similar loss **Frequently experiencing pain (or other symptoms) that the deceased person had, hearing the voice of (or seeing) the deceased person **Experiencing intense emotional or physiological reactivity to memories of the person who died or to reminders of the loss **Changes in behavior due to avoidance (or its opposite, excessive proximity-seeking—refraining from going places, doing things, or having contact with things that are reminders of the loss; feeling drawn to reminders of the person—wanting to see, touch, hear or smell things to feel close to the person who died). Both symptoms may coexist in the same individual. *Duration of symptoms and impairment of at least one month *Symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational or other major areas of functioning, where impairment is not explicable as a culturally appropriate response
== Incidence == CGD is an atypical grief response, occurring only in a minority of the bereaved population.<ref name="sixteen" /><ref name="twentytwo" /> It is considered more common in those experiencing disasters,<ref name="five" /><ref name="seventeen" /><ref name="fortyone">Ghaffari-Nejad A, Ahmadi-Mousavi M, Gandomkar M, Reihani-Kermani H. The prevalence of complicated grief among bam earthquake survivors in iran. Arch Iran Med 2007;10:525–528.</ref><ref name="seventytwo">Shear, M. K., McLaughlin, K. A., Ghesquiere, A., Gruber, M. J., Sampson, N. A., & Kessler, R. C. (2011). COMPLICATED GRIEF ASSOCIATED WITH HURRICANE KATRINA. Depression and Anxiety, 28(8), 648-657. doi:10.1002/da.20865</ref> violence<ref name="fortytwo">Mancini A, Prati G, Black S. Self-worth mediates the effects of violent loss on ptsd symptoms. J Trauma Stress 2010, in press.</ref><ref name="fortyfour">Mitchell AM, Kim Y, Prigerson HG, Mortimer-Stephens M. Complicated grief in survivors of suicide. Crisis 2004;25:12–18.</ref><ref name="fortyfive">Vessier-Batchen M, Douglas D. Coping and complicated grief in survivors of homicide and suicide decedents. J Forensic Nurs 2006;2:25–32.</ref><ref name="fortysix">Melhem NM, Day N, Shear MK, et al. Traumatic grief among adolescents exposed to a peer’s suicide. Am J Psychiatry 2004; 161:1411–1416.</ref> or the loss of a child.<ref name="fortyseven">Keesee NJ, Currier JM, Neimeyer RA. Predictors of grief following the death of one’s child: the contribution of finding meaning. J Clin Psychol 2008;64:1145–1163.</ref><ref name="fortyeight">Meert KL, Thurston CS, Thomas R. Parental coping and bereavement outcome after the death of a child in the pediatric intensive care unit. ''[[Pediatric Critical Care Medicine]]'' 2001;2:324–328.</ref><ref name="fortynine">Murphy SA. The loss of a child: sudden death and extended illness perspectives. In: Stroebe M, Hansson RO, Schut H, Stroebe W, editors. Handbook of Bereavement Research and Practice: Advances in Theory and Intervention. Washington, DC: American Psychological Association; 2008.</ref>
It has also been found in family members (or friends) of: * Patients with life-threatening illnesses<ref name="twentysix" /><ref name="twentyseven">Tomarken A, Holland J, Schachter S, et al. Factors of complicated grief pre-death in caregivers of cancer patients. Psychooncology 2008;17:105–111.</ref><ref name="fifty">Anderson WG, Arnold RM, Angus DC, Bryce CL. Posttraumatic stress and complicated grief in family members of patients in the intensive care unit. J Gen Intern Med 2008;23: 1871–1876.</ref><ref name="fiftyone">Siegel MD, Hayes E, Vanderwerker LC, et al. Psychiatric illness in the next of kin of patients who die in the intensive care unit. Crit Care Med 2008;36:1722–1728.</ref> * Suicides and homicides<ref name="fortyfive" /><ref name="fortythree">Currier JM, Holland JM, Neimeyer RA. Sense-making, grief, and the experience of violent loss: toward a mediational model. Death Stud 2006;30:403–428.</ref>
CGD is found to be prevalent cross-culturally in Europe,<ref name="eighteen" /><ref name="twentyone" /><ref name="fiftytwo">Forstmeier S, Maercker A. Comparison of two diagnostic systems for complicated grief. J Affect Disord 2007;99:203–211.</ref><ref name="fiftythree">Kersting A, Kroker K, Horstmann J, et al. Complicated grief in patients with unipolar depression. J Affect Disord 2009;118:201–204.</ref><ref name="fiftyfour">Kersting A, Kroker K, Steinhard J, et al. Complicated grief after traumatic loss: a 14-month follow up study. Eur Arch Psychiatry Clin Neurosci 2007;257:437–443.</ref><ref name="fiftyfive">Langner R, Maercker A. Complicated grief as a stress response disorder: evaluating diagnostic criteria in a german sample. J Psychosom Res 2005;58:235–242.</ref><ref name="fiftysix">Parkes CM. Symposium on complicated grief. OMEGA 2005–2006;52:1–7.</ref><ref name="fiftyseven">Stroebe M, Schut H. Complicated grief: a conceptual analysis of the field. OMEGA 2005–2006;52:53–70.</ref><ref name="fiftyeight">Morina N, Rudari V, Bleichhardt G, Prigerson HG. Prolonged grief disorder, depression, and posttraumatic stress disorder among bereaved kosovar civilian war survivors: a preliminary investigation. International Journal of Social Psychiatry 2010;56:288–297.</ref> the Middle East,<ref name="fortyone" /><ref name="fiftynine">Prigerson H, Ahmed I, Silverman GK, et al. Rates and risks of complicated grief among psychiatric clinic patients in karachi, pakistan. Death Stud 2002;26:781–792.</ref> Africa,<ref name="sixty">Schaal S, Elbert T, Neuner F. Prolonged grief disorder and depression in widows due to the rwandan genocide. Omega (Westport) 2009;59:203–219.</ref> and Asia.<ref name="twentysix" /><ref name="sixtyone">Laor N, Wolmer L, Kora M, et al. Posttraumatic, dissociative and grief symptoms in Turkish children exposed to the 1999 earthquakes. J Nerv Ment Dis 2002;190:824–832.</ref><ref name="sixtytwo">Bonanno GA, Papa A, Lalande K, et al. Grief processing and deliberate grief avoidance: a prospective comparison of bereaved spouses and parents in the united states and the People’s Republic of China. J Consult Clin Psychol 2005;73:86–98.</ref><ref name="sixtythree">Ito M. Complicated grief among general Japanese population: validity and reliability of Brief Grief Questionnaire. Presentation World Congress of Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies, Boston, MA; 2010.</ref><ref name="sixtyfour">Nakajima S, Shirai A, Maki S, et al. Mental health of the families of crime victims and factors related to their recovery. Seishin Shinkeigaku Zasshi 2009;111:423–429.</ref><ref name="sixtyfive">Fujisawa D, Miyashita M, Nakajima S, Ito M, Kato M, Kim Y. Prevalence and determinants of complicated grief in general population. J Affect Disord 2010;127:352–358.</ref>
== Treatment == CGD is relatively unresponsive to antidepressants<ref name="sixtysix">Pasternak RE, Reynolds III CF, Schlernitzauer M, et al. Acute open-trial nortriptyline therapy of bereavement-related depression in late life. J Clin Psychiatry 1991;52:307–310.</ref> or [[interpersonal psychotherapy]];<ref name="sixtyseven">Reynolds 3rd CF, Miller MD, Pasternak RE, et al. Treatment of bereavement-related major depressive episodes in later life: a controlled study of acute and continuation treatment with nortriptyline and interpersonal psychotherapy. Am J Psychiatry 1999;156:202–208.</ref> however, recent studies support the use of CG-targeted psychotherapy<ref name="twentyseven" /><ref name="sixtyeight">Shear MK, Frank E, Foa E, et al. Traumatic grief treatment: a pilot study. Am J Psychiatry 2001;158:1506–1508.</ref><ref name="sixtynine">Shear K, Frank E, Houck PR, Reynolds 3rd CF. Treatment of complicated grief: a randomized controlled trial. J Am Med Assoc 2005;293:2601–2608.</ref> (similar to PTSD-targeted psychotherapy). Other methods of psycho-pharmacological treatment are under investigation.
== {{anchor|CGD and Bereavement Related Adjustment Disorder}}CGD and bereavement-related adjustment disorder== Although the DSM-5 work groups have suggested using "adjustment disorder, specified as bereavement-related" to diagnose complicated grief, opposing opinions contend that this does not fit the nature of CGD and is an inappropriate diagnosis for those suffering from CGD.<ref name="one" /><ref name="seventyone">Shear, M. K. (2011). BEREAVEMENT AND THE DSM5. Omega-Journal of Death and Dying, 64(2), 101-118. doi:10.2190</ref>
== {{anchor|Ethical Considerations}}Ethical considerations == === {{anchor|Pathologizing or misdiagnosing normal grief}}Medicalizing (or misdiagnosing) normal grief === Following the DSM-5 work groups’ recommendation to remove the bereavement-exclusionary criteria,<ref name="seventy">Wakefield and First, 2012 Wakefield JC, First MB. Validity of the bereavement exclusion to major depression: does the empirical evidence support the proposal to eliminate the exclusion in DSM-5?. World Psychiatry 2012; 11: 3-10.</ref> there is some concern that the addition of CGD may increase the possibility of [[Medicalization|medicalizing]] the grieving process. However, proponents of CGD claim that with proper clinical assessment only those with abnormally incapacitating levels of grief will receive this diagnosis and benefit from treatment. Furthermore, despite the possibility of diagnosis-related stigma the clinical necessity for treatment is a priority for those suffering from CGD.<ref name="one" />
=== Cultural norms for grief === An individual’s culture plays a large role in determining an inappropriate pattern of grief, and it is necessary to consider cultural norms before reaching a CGD diagnosis.<ref name="one" /> There are cultural differences in expected emotional levels, their expression and duration; the external symptoms of grief differ in non-Western cultures, presenting increased [[somatization]].<ref name="seventythree">Horwitz, A. V., & Wakefield, J. C. (2007). The Loss of Sadness: How Psychiatry Transformed Normal Sorrow Into Depressive Disorder. Oxford University Press.</ref>
== See also == *[[Ghost sickness]]
== References == {{Reflist|3}} Tafà, M., Cerniglia, L., Cimino, S., Ballarotto, G., Marzilli, E., & Tambelli, R. (2018). Predictive values of early parental loss and psychopathological risk for physical problems in early adolescents. Frontiers in psychology, 9.
== External links == * [http://www.complicatedgrief.org/ Complicated Grief Program] * [http://www.slate.com/articles/life/grieving/2012/03/complicated_grief_and_the_dsm_the_wrongheaded_movement_to_list_mourning_as_a_mental_disorder_.html Is mourning madness?] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/29/health/29grief.html?pagewanted=all After a Death, an Extreme Form of Grieving] * [http://www.apa.org/ethics/code/index.aspx APA’s Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct]

revision.text:
The '''compression of morbidity''' in [[public health]] is a hypothesis put forth<ref> {{cite journal |pages=130–5 |doi=10.1056/NEJM198007173030304 |url=http://aramis.stanford.edu/downloads/1980FriesNEJM130.pdf |title=Aging, Natural Death, and the Compression of Morbidity |year=1980 |last1=Fries |first1=James F. |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=303 |issue=3 |pmid=7383070|pmc=2567746 }}</ref> by James Fries, professor of medicine at Stanford University School of Medicine. The hypothesis was supported by a 1998 study of 1700 [[University of Pennsylvania]] alumni over a period of 20 years.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=1035–41 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199804093381506 |title=Aging, Health Risks, and Cumulative Disability |year=1998 |last1=Vita |first1=Anthony J. |last2=Terry |first2=Richard B. |last3=Hubert |first3=Helen B. |last4=Fries |first4=James F. |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=338 |issue=15 |pmid=9535669}}</ref>
Fries' hypothesis is that the burden of lifetime illness may be compressed into a shorter period before the time of death, if the age of onset of the first chronic infirmity can be postponed.<ref name="Fries">{{cite journal |pages=1163–6 |doi=10.2105/AJPH.2008.135731 |pmc=2424092 |title=James Fries: Healthy Aging Pioneer |year=2008 |last1=Swartz |first1=Aimee |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=98 |issue=7 |pmid=18511711}}</ref> This hypothesis contrasts to the view that as the age of countries' populations tends to increase over time, they will become increasingly infirm and consume an ever-larger proportion of the national budget in healthcare costs.<ref>"The compression of morbidity was prophetic in the sense that Jim looked at the reduction of morbidity and disability at a time when most gerontologists and epidemiologists thought we would see a pandemic of disability." —Richard Suzman, quoted in {{harvnb|Swartz|2008}}</ref>
Fries posited that if the hypothesis is confirmed, healthcare costs and patient health overall will be improved.<ref name="Fries"/> In order to confirm this hypothesis, the evidence must show that it is possible to delay the onset of infirmity, and that corresponding increases in longevity will at least be modest. The evidence is at best mixed. Vincent Mor's "The Compression of Morbidity Hypothesis: A Review of Research and Prospects for the Future" argues that "Cross-national evidence for the validity of the compression of morbidity hypothesis originally proposed by Fries is generally accepted. Generational improvements in education and the increased availability of adaptive technologies and even medical treatments that enhance quality of life have facilitated continued independence of older persons in the industrialized world. Whether this trend continues may depend upon the effect of the obesity epidemic on the next generation of older people."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1532-5415.2005.53496.x|title=The Compression of Morbidity Hypothesis: A Review of Research and Prospects for the Future|last=Mor|first=Vincent|date=2005|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> See also "Mortality and Morbidity Trends: Is There Compression of Morbidity?" for recent evidence against the hypothesis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crimmins|first=Eileen M.|last2=Beltrán-Sánchez|first2=Hiram|date=2011-01-01|title=Mortality and Morbidity Trends: Is There Compression of Morbidity?|url=https://academic.oup.com/psychsocgerontology/article/66B/1/75/583170/Mortality-and-Morbidity-Trends-Is-There|journal=The Journals of Gerontology: Series B|volume=66B|issue=1|pages=75–86|doi=10.1093/geronb/gbq088|issn=1079-5014|pmc=3001754}}</ref> There may also be age versus cohort effects.<ref>http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/pag/30/2/462/</ref>
==See also== *[[Successful aging]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal |pages=801–23 |doi=10.1111/j.1468-0009.2005.00401.x |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0009.2005.00401.x/pdf |title=The Compression of Morbidity |year=2005 |last1=Fries |first1=James F. |journal=The Milbank Quarterly |volume=83 |issue=4 |pmid=16279968 |pmc=2690269}} *{{cite news |first=Jane E. |last=Brody |date=August 25, 2008 |title=Living Longer, in Good Health to the End |work=The New York Times |page=D7 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/26/health/26brod.html}} *[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/08/well/move/lessons-on-aging-well-from-a-105-year-old-cyclist.html Gretchen Reynolds (8 February 2017) "Lessons on Aging Well from a 105-Year-Old Cyclist"] ''[[The New York Times]]'' accessdate=2017-02-14

{{refimprove|date=July 2011}}
{{Infobox organization | image = File:Logoecs.jpg | alt = Logo of the European Calcium Society | formation = 1989 | type = Non-profit | purpose = Scientific exchange | leader_title = President | leader_name = Catherine Leclerc | leader_title2 = Vice-president | leader_name2 = Annette Draeger | leader_name3 = Luc Leybaert | leader_title3 = Treasurer | main_organ = General assembly | name = European Calcium Society | image_size = 282 | abbreviation = ECS | founder = Roland Pochet, Rosario Donato, Claus Heizmann, Jacques Haiech | fields = [[Calcium signaling]] | membership = ~300 | sec_gen = Jan B. Parys | website = {{url|http:/calciumsociety.eu}} }}
The '''European Calcium Society''' is a non-profit society that aims to develop relationships between different generations of scientists in Europe working in the field of [[calcium signaling]] and the [[protein]]s involved in the Calcium Toolkit.
== Origin ==
The First European Symposium took place in 1989 and covered [[Calcium metabolism|calcium binding proteins]] in normal and transformed cells. The symposium resulted from a 30 month gestation.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}}
The symposium filled a gap given the lack of European fora in which young European researchers could participate (the International Symposium was held in [[Asilomar State Beach|Asilomar, CA]] 1986, in [[Nagoya]] in 1988, in [[Banff, Alberta|Banff, Canada]], etc.)
A [[European Union]] grant called Stimulation Action was awarded to [[Roland Pochet]] in November 1986. Long discussions in 1988 between Pochet and Jacques Haiech at [[Mont Sainte-Odile]] who pointed out the importance of European researchers in calcium binding proteins (Hamoir, Liége,1955,<ref name=Hamoir1955> {{cite journal | last = Hamoir | first = G. | date = 1955 | title = Fish Proteins | journal = Advances in Protein Chemistry | volume = 10 | pages = 227–288 | doi = 10.1016/S0065-3233(08)60106-0 | pmid = 13282763 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0065-3233(08)60106-0}}</ref> Pechere, Montpellier, 1965,<ref name=Focant1965> {{cite journal | last1 = Focant | first1 = B. | last2 = Pechére | first2 = J. F. | date = March 1965 | title = Contribution a L'étude des Protéines de Faible Poids Moléculaire des Myogènes de Vertébrés Inférieurs |trans-title=Contribution to the study of low molecular weight proteins in myogens of lower vertebrates | language = French | journal = Archives of Physiology and Biochemistry | volume = 73 | issue = 2 | pages = 334–354 | doi = 10.3109/13813456509084256 | pmid = 4158093}}</ref> Drabikowski, Varsovie, 1970<ref name=Drabikowski1970> {{cite journal | last1 = Drabikowski | first1 = W. | last2 = Baryłko | first2 = B. | last3 = Dąbrowska | first3 = R. | last4 = Sarzała | first4 = M.G. | date = November 8, 1970 | title = Is troponin the Ca++-receptive protein in the contractile system? | journal = Liefe Sciences, Part II | volume = 9 | issue = 21 | pages = 1225–1233 | doi = 10.1016/0024-3205(70)90234-1 | pmid = 4249742 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0024-3205(70)90234-1}}</ref>) and the strong support received from [[Claus Heizmann]].
==History==
1997 was important because the “European Calcium Society” was registered under E.U. guidelines, which had earlier rejected a proposal to finance the fourth symposium because of lack of structure. In 1997 they created the group's first ECS Web site,<ref>[http://calciumsociety.eu Official ECS website]</ref> logo, newsletter and a set of statutes published in the “Moniteur belge” as an “Arrêté Royal du 22 septembre 1997” signed by [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]].<ref>[http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/tsv/tsvf.htm]</ref>
== 1998-2005 ==
1998-2005 was a consolidation period. Since 2000, ECS has been selected as an EU High-level Scientific Conference allowing it to offer grants to young European researchers. The board was enlarged to include Volker Gerke and Steve Moss. ECS provided posters, prizes and recently special grants for young researchers.
== Youth emphasis == Since its creation, 30 to 35% of the participants at ECS symposia were young researchers (below 35 years old). Encouraging young researchers to participate has always been one of the main objectives.
==Publication==
Since 1992 Heizmann has sponsored the publication of significant articles in the scientific journal [[Biochimica et Biophysica Acta]]. A newsletter is also produced twice a year (May and November).
==Workshops==
In 2007, ECS launched its first workshop, in [[Ariège (department)|Ariège]] (France). The second took place in June 2009 in [[Smolenice]] (Slovakia).
== Sources == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:International scientific societies of Europe]] [[Category:Physiology organizations]] [[Category:Calcium]] [[Category:Human homeostasis]]

{{mergeto|Environmental factor|date=October 2018}} {{advert|date=October 2018}} {{primary|date=October 2018}} The '''exposome''' encompasses the totality of human environmental (i.e. non-genetic) [[Exposure assessment|exposure]]s from conception onwards, complementing the [[genome]], first proposed in 2005 by a [[Epidemiology of cancer|cancer epidemiologist]]. As of 2016 it may not be possible to measure or model.
==Definition== The exposome was first proposed in 2005 by [[Epidemiology of cancer|cancer epidemiologist]] Christopher Paul Wild in an article entitled "Complementing the genome with an "exposome": the outstanding challenge of environmental exposure measurement in molecular epidemiology".<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wild |first=CP |title= Complementing the genome with an "exposome": the outstanding challenge of environmental exposure measurement in molecular epidemiology |journal= Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention |date= Aug 2005 |volume=14 |issue=8 |pages=1847–50 |pmid= 16103423 |doi= 10.1158/1055-9965.EPI-05-0456}}</ref> The concept of the exposome and how to assess it has led to lively discussions with varied views in 2010,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors= Rappaport SM, Smith MT |year=2010 |title= Epidemiology. Environment and disease risks |url= |journal= Science |volume= 330 |issue= 6003 |pages= 460–461 |doi= 10.1126/science.1192603|pmid=20966241 |pmc= 4841276 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author= Rappaport SM |year= 2011 |title= Implications of the exposome for exposure science |journal= J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol |volume= 21 |issue= 1 |pages= 5–9 |doi= 10.1038/jes.2010.50|pmid= 21081972 }}</ref>2012,<ref name="Wild 24–32">{{cite journal |last=Wild |first=CP |title= The exposome: from concept to utility |journal= International Journal of Epidemiology |date=Feb 2012 |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=24–32 |pmid= 22296988 |doi= 10.1093/ije/dyr236}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Peters A, Hoek G, Katsouyanni K | year = 2012 |title= Understanding the link between environmental exposures and health: does the exposome promise too much? |journal= Epidemiol Community Health |volume= 66 |issue= 2|pages= 103–105 |doi= 10.1136/jech-2011-200643 | pmid = 22080817 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors= Buck Louis GM, Sundaram R |year=2012 |title= Exposome: time for transformative research |url= |journal= Stat Med. |volume= 31 |issue= 22 |pages= 2569–75 |doi= 10.1002/sim.5496|pmid=22969025 |pmc= 3842164 }}</ref><ref name = "CDC">[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (2012). [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/exposome/ "Exposome and Exposomics"]. Retrieved 5 March 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1= Buck Louis G. M. |author2= Yeung E. |author3= Sundaram R. |author4=et al |year= 2013 |title= The Exposome – Exciting Opportunities for Discoveries in Reproductive and Perinatal Epidemiology |url= |journal= Paediatric and Perinatal Epidemiology |volume= 27 |issue= 3|pages= 229–236 |doi= 10.1111/ppe.12040 |pmid= 23574410 |pmc= 3625972 }}</ref><ref name="dx.doi.org">{{cite journal |vauthors= Vrijheid M, Slama R, Robinson O, Chatzi L, Coen M, ''et al''. |year= 2014|title= The Human Early-Life Exposome (HELIX): Project Rationale and Design |journal= Environ Health Perspect |volume= 122|issue= 6|pages= 535–544|doi= 10.1289/ehp.1307204 |pmid= 24610234|pmc= 4048258}}</ref> and 2014,<ref>{{cite journal |author1= Miller Gary W. |author2=Jones Dean P | year = 2014 | title = The Nature of Nurture: Refining the Definition of the Exposome | journal = [[Toxicological Sciences]] | volume = 137 | issue = 1| pages = 1–2 | doi=10.1093/toxsci/kft251 | pmid=24213143 | pmc=3871934}}</ref><ref>Porta M, editor. Greenland S, Hernán M, dos Santos Silva I, Last JM, associate editors (2014). ''[http://global.oup.com/academic/product/a-dictionary-of-epidemiology-9780199976737?cc=us&lang=en A dictionary of epidemiology]'', 6th. edition. New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|9780199976737}}</ref>
In his 2005 article, Wild stated, "At its most complete, the exposome encompasses life-course [[environmental exposure]]s (including [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] factors), from the [[prenatal]] period onwards." The concept was first proposed to draw attention to the need for better and more complete environmental exposure data for causal research, in order to balance the investment in genetics. According to Wild, even incomplete versions of the exposome could be useful to [[epidemiology]]. In 2012, Wild outlined methods, including personal sensors, [[biomarker]]s, and '[[omics]]' technologies, to better define the exposome.<ref name="Wild 24–32"/> He described three overlapping domains within the exposome: # a general [[external environment]] including the [[urban environment]], [[education]], [[climate]] factors, [[social capital]], [[stress (psychological)|stress]], # a specific external environment with specific [[contaminant]]s, [[radiation]], [[infection]]s, [[Lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] factors (e.g. [[tobacco]], [[alcohol]]), [[diet (nutrition)|diet]], [[physical activity]], etc. # an internal environment to include internal biological factors such as [[metabolic]] factors, [[hormones]], [[gut microflora]], [[inflammation]], [[oxidative stress]]. In late 2013, this definition was explained in greater depth in the first book on the exposome.<ref>{{Cite book |author= Gary Miller |isbn= 978-0124172173 |date= 2 December 2013 |pages=118 |title= The Exposome: A Primer |publisher= Elsevier |url= https://www.elsevier.com/books/the-exposome/miller/978-0-12-417217-3|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=G x E = ?| url=http://scitechconnect.elsevier.com/g-x-e/|author= Gary Miller|date=20 November 2013|publisher=Elsevier|work=Sci Connect|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref> In 2014, the same author revised the definition to include the body's response with its endogenous metabolic processes which alter the processing of chemicals.<ref>{{cite journal |author1= Miller Gary W. |author2=Jones Dean P. |date= January 2014 |title= The Nature of Nurture: Refining the Definition of the Exposome |journal= [[Toxicological Sciences]] |volume=137 |issue=1 |pages= 1–2 |pmid= 24213143 |doi= 10.1093/toxsci/kft251 | pmc=3871934}}</ref>
==Measurement== For complex disorders, specific genetic causes appear to account for only 10-30% of the disease incidence, but there has been no standard or systematic way to measure the influence of environmental exposures. Some studies into the interaction of genetic and environmental factors in the incidence of [[diabetes]] have demonstrated that "environment-wide association studies" (EWAS, or exposome-wide association studies) may be feasible.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Patel|first=CJ|author2=Bhattacharya, J |author3=Butte, AJ |title=An Environment-Wide Association Study (EWAS) on type 2 diabetes mellitus.|journal=PLoS ONE|date=May 20, 2010| volume=5| issue=5| pages=e10746| pmid=20505766|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0010746|pmc=2873978}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Patel|first=CJ|author2=Chen, R |author3=Kodama, K |author4=Ioannidis, JP |author5= Butte, AJ |title=Systematic identification of interaction effects between genome- and environment-wide associations in type 2 diabetes mellitus| url=http://download.springer.com/static/pdf/676/art%253A10.1007%252Fs00439-012-1258-z.pdf?auth66=1425526047_d503d7888be4f8f7c25b85cac0e83d09&ext=.pdf | journal=Human Genetics| date=20 January 2013| pmid=23334806|accessdate=4 March 2015 |doi=10.1007/s00439-012-1258-z |volume=132 |issue=5 |pages=495–508 |pmc=3625410}}{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref> However, it is not clear what data sets are most appropriate to represent the value of "E".<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Smith Martyn T. |author2=Rappaport Stephen M. | date = August 2009 | title = Building Exposure Biology Centers to Put the E into "G × E" Interaction Studies | journal = [[Environmental Health Perspectives]] | volume = 117 | issue = 8| pages = A334–A335 | pmc=2721881 | pmid=19672377 | doi=10.1289/ehp.12812}}</ref>
==Research initiatives== As of 2016, it may not be possible to measure or model the full exposome, but several European projects have started to make first attempts. In 2012, the [[European Commission]] awarded two large grants to pursue exposome-related research.<ref name=nature>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.nature.com/news/daily-dose-of-toxics-to-be-tracked-1.11901 |title=Daily dose of toxics to be tracked |journal=Nature |volume=491 |issue=7426 |pages=647 |last1=Callaway|first1= Ewen |date=27 November 2012 |accessdate=4 March 2013|doi=10.1038/491647a |pmid=23192121 }}</ref>
The HELIX project at the [[Barcelona]]-based Centre for Research in Environmental Epidemiology was launched around 2014, and aimed to develop an early-life exposome.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vrijheid |first1=M |last2=Slama |first2=R |last3=Robinson |first3=O |last4=Chatzi |first4=L |last5=Coen |first5=M |last6=van den Hazel |first6=P |last7=Thomsen |first7=C |last8=Wright |first8=J |last9=Athersuch |first9=TJ |last10=Avellana |first10=N |last11=Basagaña |first11=X |last12=Brochot |first12=C |last13=Bucchini |first13=L |last14=Bustamante |first14=M |last15=Carracedo |first15=A |last16=Casas |first16=M |last17=Estivill |first17=X |last18=Fairley |first18=L |last19=van Gent |first19=D |last20=Gonzalez |first20=JR |last21=Granum |first21=B |last22=Gražulevičienė |first22=R |last23=Gutzkow |first23=KB |last24=Julvez |first24=J |last25=Keun |first25=HC |last26=Kogevinas |first26=M |last27=McEachan |first27=RR |last28=Meltzer |first28=HM |last29=Sabidó |first29=E |last30=Schwarze |first30=PE |last31=Siroux |first31=V |last32=Sunyer |first32=J |last33=Want |first33=EJ |last34=Zeman |first34=F |last35=Nieuwenhuijsen |first35=MJ |title=The human early-life exposome (HELIX): project rationale and design. |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |date=June 2014 |volume=122 |issue=6 |pages=535–44 |doi=10.1289/ehp.1307204 |pmid=24610234 |pmc=4048258}}</ref>
A second project, Exposomics, based at [[Imperial College London]], launched in 2012, aimed to use smartphones utilizine GPS and environmental sensors to assess exposures.<ref name=nature/><ref>[http://www.exposomicsproject.eu/ About Exposomics] EU</ref>
In late 2013, a major initiative called the "Health and Environment-Wide Associations based on Large Scale population Surveys" or HEALS, began. Touted as the largest environmental health-related study in Europe, HEALS proposes to adopt a paradigm defined by interactions between DNA sequence, epigenetic DNA modifications, gene expression, and environmental factors.<ref>{{cite web|title=HEALS-EU.|url=http://www.heals-eu.eu/|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref>
In December 2011, the US [[National Academy of Sciences]] hosted a meeting entitled "Emerging Technologies for Measuring Individual Exposomes."<ref>{{cite web|title=National Academy of Sciences meeting|url=http://nas-sites.org/emergingscience/meetings/exposome/|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref> A [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] overview, "Exposome and Exposomics", outlines the three priority areas for researching the occupational exposome as identified by the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]].<ref name="CDC"/> The [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH) has invested in technologies supporting exposome-related research including biosensors, and supports research on [[gene-environment interaction]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=NIEHS Gene-Environment studies|url=http://www.niehs.nih.gov/health/topics/science/gene-env/index.cfm|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Genes and Environment Initiative|url=http://www.genome.gov/19518663|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref>
==Proposed Human Exposome Project (HEP)==
The idea of a Human Exposome Project, analogous to the [[Human Genome Project]], has been proposed and discussed in numerous scientific meetings, but as of 2017, no such project exists. Given the lack of clarity on how science would go about pursuing such a project, support has been lacking.<ref>Arnaud, Celia Henry (16 August 2010). [https://pubs.acs.org/cen/science/88/8833sci1.html "Exposing The Exposome"]. ''Chemical & Engineering News'', Vol. 88, No. 33, pp. 42-44. [[American Chemical Society]]. Retrieved 5 March 2013.</ref> Reports on the issue include:
*a 2011 review on the exposome and [[exposure science]] by [[Paul Lioy]] and Stephen Rappaport, "Exposure science and the exposome: an opportunity for coherence in the environmental health sciences" in the journal ''[[Environmental Health Perspectives]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lioy|first=PJ|author2=Rappaport, SM|title=Exposure science and the exposome: an opportunity for coherence in the environmental health sciences|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|date=Nov 2011| volume=119|issue=11|pages=A466–7|pmid=22171373|doi=10.1289/ehp.1104387|pmc=3226514}}</ref> *a 2012 report from the [[United States National Research Council]] "Exposure Science in the 21st Century: A Vision and A Strategy", outlining the challenges in systematic evaluations of the exposome.<ref>{{cite web|title=NRC report supports NIEHS vision of the exposome|url=http://www.niehs.nih.gov/news/newsletter/2012/10/spotlight-nrc/index.htm|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Exposure Science in the 21st Century: A Vision and a Strategy|url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=13507|accessdate=21 January 2013|isbn=9780309264686|date=2012-09-07|last1=Council|first1=National Research|last2=Studies|first2=Division on Earth Life|last3=Toxicology|first3=Board on Environmental Studies and|last4=Century|first4=Committee on Human Environmental Exposure Science in the 21st}}</ref>
==Related fields== The concept of the exposome has contributed to the 2010 proposal of a new [[paradigm]] in disease [[phenotype]], "the unique disease principle": Every individual has a unique disease process different from any other individual, considering uniqueness of the exposome and its unique influence on molecular pathologic processes including alterations in the [[interactome]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ogino S, Lochhead P, Chan AT, et al | year = 2013 | title = Molecular pathological epidemiology of epigenetics: emerging integrative science to analyze environment, host, and disease | url = | journal = Mod Pathol | volume = 26 | issue = 4| pages = 465–484 | doi=10.1038/modpathol.2012.214 | pmid=23307060 | pmc=3637979}}</ref> This principle was first described in neoplastic diseases as "the unique tumor principle".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ogino S, Fuchs CS, Giovannucci E | year = 2012 | title = How many molecular subtypes? Implications of the unique tumor principle in personalized medicine | url = | journal = Expert Rev Mol Diagn | volume = 12 | issue = 6| pages = 621–628 | doi=10.1586/erm.12.46 | pmid=22845482 | pmc=3492839}}</ref> Based on this unique disease principle, the interdisciplinary field of [[molecular pathological epidemiology]] (MPE) integrates [[molecular pathology]] and epidemiology.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ogino S, Stampfer M | year = 2010 | title = Lifestyle factors and microsatellite instability in colorectal cancer: the evolving field of molecular pathological epidemiology | url = | journal = J Natl Cancer Inst | volume = 102 | issue = 6| pages = 365–367 | doi=10.1093/jnci/djq031 | pmid=20208016 | pmc=2841039}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Envirome]] * [[Public health]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: fm-2030.us in external links redirects to malware site, so i removed it
revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = FM-2030 | image = File:FM2030.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Fereidoun M. Esfandiary | birth_date = {{birth date|1930|10|15}} | birth_place = [[City of Brussels|Brussels]], Belgium | death_date = {{death date and age|2000|7|8|1930|10|15}} | death_place = New York City, New York, U.S. | occupation = Writer, philosopher, teacher, consultant | nationality = [[Iranian-American]] | genre = Science fiction, [[futurology]] | movement = [[Transhumanism]] | notableworks = ''Are You a Transhuman?'' }}
{{contains Perso-Arabic text}}
'''FM-2030''' (October 15, 1930 – July 8, 2000) was a Belgian-born [[Iranian-American]] author, teacher, [[Transhumanism|transhumanist]] philosopher, [[futurist]], consultant and athlete.<ref name="nytimes obituary">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/11/us/futurist-known-as-fm-2030-is-dead-at-69.html |title=Futurist Known as FM-2030 Is Dead at 69 |accessdate=2009-08-25 |last= Martin|first= Douglas|date=July 11, 2000 |publisher=The New York Times }}</ref> FM-2030 was born '''Fereidoun M. Esfandiary''' ({{lang-fa|فریدون اسفندیاری}}).
He became notable as a transhumanist with the book ''Are You a Transhuman?: Monitoring and Stimulating Your Personal Rate of Growth in a Rapidly Changing World'', published in 1989. In addition, he wrote a number of works of fiction under his original name F.M. Esfandiary.
==Early life and education== The son of an [[Foreign relations of Iran|Iranian diplomat]], he travelled widely as a child, living in 17 countries by age 11; then, as a young man, he [[Iran at the 1948 Summer Olympics#Basketball|represented Iran]] as a basketball player at the [[1948 Summer Olympics|1948 Olympic Games]] in London<ref name="nyt">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/11/us/futurist-known-as-fm-2030-is-dead-at-69.html |title=Futurist Known as FM-2030 Is Dead at 69 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=July 11, 2000 |accessdate=October 8, 2015}}</ref> and served on the [[UNSCOP|United Nations Conciliation Commission for Palestine]] from 1952 to 1954.<ref name=nypl>{{cite web|url=http://www.nypl.org/research/chss/spe/rbk/faids/fm2030.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326114647/http://www.nypl.org/research/chss/spe/rbk/faids/fm2030.pdf|archivedate=2009-03-26|title=F. M. Esfandiary / FM-2030 Papers : 1943-2000|date=May 2007}}</ref>
==Name change== In the mid-1970s F.M. Esfandiary legally<ref name="nyt" /> changed his name to FM-2030 for two main reasons. Firstly, to reflect the hope and belief that he would live to celebrate his 100th birthday in 2030; secondly, and more importantly, to break free of the widespread practice of [[naming conventions]] that he saw as rooted in a [[collectivist]] mentality, and existing only as a relic of humankind's tribalistic past. He viewed traditional names as almost always stamping a label of [[collective identity]]—varying from [[gender]] to nationality—on the individual, thereby existing as prima facie elements of thought processes in the human cultural fabric, that tended to degenerate into stereotyping, factionalism, and discrimination. In his own words, "Conventional names define a person's past: ancestry, ethnicity, nationality, religion. I am not who I was ten years ago and certainly not who I will be in twenty years. [...] The name 2030 reflects my conviction that the years around 2030 will be a magical time. In 2030 we will be [[ageless]] and everyone will have an excellent chance to live forever. 2030 is a dream and a goal."<ref name=npr>{{cite web|author=All Things Considered |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1076532 |title=Fm-2030 |publisher=NPR |date=2000-07-11 |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref>
==Personal life== He was a lifelong vegetarian and said he would not eat anything that had a mother.<ref name="cryonics 2000">{{cite news|url=http://www.alcor.org/cryonics/cryonics2000-4.pdf |title=A Tribute to FM-2030 |access-date=2009-08-25 |last= Chamberlain|first= Fred|date=Winter 2000 |publisher=Alcor Life Extension Foundation }}</ref> FM-2030 once said, "I am a 21st century person who was accidentally launched in the 20th. I have a deep nostalgia for the future."<ref>{{cite web|author=Greenwich Village Gazette (A New1.com Publication) |url=http://www.nycny.com/columns/nichols/nichols09-15-00.html |title=Greenwich Village Gazette: Columns: Gay Today: Jack Nichols |publisher=Nycny.com |date= |access-date=2011-03-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714215926/http://www.nycny.com/columns/nichols/nichols09-15-00.html |archivedate=2011-07-14 |df= }}</ref> He taught at [[The New School]], [[University of California, Los Angeles]], and [[Florida International University]].<ref name="nytimes obituary"/> He worked as a corporate consultant for [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] and [[J. C. Penney]].<ref name="nytimes obituary"/> He was also an atheist.<ref>Esfandiary, F.M. Upwingers: A Futurist Manifesto. p. 185.</ref>
==Death== On July 8, 2000, FM-2030 died from [[pancreatic cancer]] and was placed in [[cryonic suspension]] at the [[Alcor Life Extension Foundation]] in [[Scottsdale, Arizona|Scottsdale]], Arizona, where his body remains today. He did not yet have remote standby arrangements, so no Alcor team member was present at his death, but FM-2030 was the first person to be [[Cryopreservation#Vitrification|vitrified]], rather than simply frozen as previous [[cryonics]] patients had been.<ref name="cryonics 2000"/> FM-2030 was survived by four sisters and one brother.<ref name="nyt" />
==Published works== ;Fiction *''The Day of Sacrifice'' (1959) available as an eBook *''The Beggar'' (1965) *''Identity Card'' (1966) ({{ISBN|0-460-03843-5}}) available as an eBook
;Non-fiction *''Optimism one; the emerging radicalism'' (1970) ({{ISBN|0-393-08611-9}}) *''UpWingers: A Futurist Manifesto'' (1973) ({{ISBN|0-381-98243-2}}) (pbk.) Available as an eBook ISBN FW00007527, Publisher: e-reads, Pub. Date: Jan 1973, File Size: 153K *''Telespheres'' (1977) ({{ISBN|0-445-04115-3}}) *''Are You a Transhuman?: Monitoring and Stimulating Your Personal Rate of Growth in a Rapidly Changing World'' (1989) ({{ISBN|0-446-38806-8}}).
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Wikiquote}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050417220231/http://www.context.org/ICLIB/IC10/Esfandry.htm Intimacy in a Fluid World, by F.M. Esfandiary] *[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1076532 NPR story about FM-2030] *[http://en.qantara.de/content/ilija-trojanow-on-fm-esfandiary-searching-for-identity-in-irans-labyrinthine-bureaucracy Ilija Trojanow on F.M. Esfandiary: Searching for Identity in Iran's Labyrinthine Bureaucracy] *[http://fm-2030.narod.ru/olderfiles/1/ARE_YOU_A_TRANSHUMAN.htm "Are You a Transhuman?: Monitoring and Stimulating Your Personal Rate of Growth in a Rapidly Changing World" (PDF)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XkMVzEft7Og FM-2030 interview on CNN Larry King Live, in 1990]
{{Iran Men Basketball Squad 1948 Summer Olympics}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:FM-2030}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:Cryonically preserved people]] [[Category:Deaths from pancreatic cancer]] [[Category:Florida International University faculty]] [[Category:Futurologists]] [[Category:Iranian atheists]] [[Category:Iranian men's basketball players|Esfandiary]] [[Category:Iranian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Iranian writers]] [[Category:Olympic basketball players of Iran|Esfandiary]] [[Category:Basketball players at the 1948 Summer Olympics|Esfandiary]] [[Category:Writers from Miami]] [[Category:The New School faculty]] [[Category:Life extensionists]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:People from Brussels]] [[Category:Iranian transhumanists]] [[Category:American atheists]] [[Category:American transhumanists]]

{{Proposed deletion/dated |concern = The decoration doesn't merit as per [[WP:NSOLDIER]], and he doesn't meet [[WP:GNG]]. |timestamp = 20181203130448 |help = }}
{{Infobox military person |name=Farid Ahmedov |birth_date={{Birth date|1986|1|19}} |death_date= {{death date and age|2010|9|4|1986|1|19}} |birth_place= [[Jalilabad District (Azerbaijan)|Jalilabad District]] |death_place= [[Tartar District]], [[Azerbaijan]] |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance=[[Republic of Azerbaijan]] |serviceyears= |rank= |commands= |battles= |awards= [[For Heroism Medal|"For heroism" Medal]] |relations= |laterwork= }} '''Farid Ahmedov''' ({{lang-az|''' Fərid Gülağa oğlu Əhmədov'''}}) (19 January 1986, [[Jalilabad District (Azerbaijan)|Jalilabad District]], [[Azerbaijan]] – 4 September 2010, [[Tartar District]], [[Azerbaijan]]) was an Azerbaijani officer. He was posthumously awarded [[For Heroism Medal]].<ref name="helo">{{cite web |url=https://president.az/articles/1011 |title= İlham Əliyev Milli Qəhrəman Mübariz İbrahimov və Fərid Əhmədovun vida mərasimində iştirak etmişdir |last=|first=|date= 7 November 2010 |website=President.az|publisher=|access-date= 30 October 2018 |quote=}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Farid Ahmedov was born on 19 January 1986 in the [[Jalilabad District (Azerbaijan)|Jalilabad District]] of Azerbaijan. In 2013 he was graduated from Secondary School No. 1 named after Nizami Ganjavi. Meanwhile, he was admitted to the Azerbaijan High Military School named after Heydar Aliyev from which he graduated with a rank of lieutenant in 1988. In 2008, he completed a training course at the Training and Education Center. From 2008 to 2009, he served as an officer in [[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Ganja]].<ref name="helo"/>
== Military career == On September 4, 2010, Ahmedov was killed in a shooting along the frontline between Azerbaijani and Armenian and Karabakh forces. The body of Farid Ahmedov remained under Armenian control for 63 days. Finally, his body was returned to Azerbaijan on November 6 following the agreement reached by presidents of [[Armenia]] and [[Azerbaijan]] in [[Astrakhan]] in October 2010.<ref name="musavat">{{cite web |url=http://musavat.com/news/ferid-ehmedov-mubarizin-cesedini-getirmeye-gedibmis_88973.html |title= FƏRİD ƏHMƏDOV MÜBARİZİN CƏSƏDİNİ GƏTİRMƏYƏ GEDİBMİŞ |last=|first=|date= 13 November 2010 |website=Musavat.com|publisher=|access-date= 30 October 2018 |quote=}}</ref>
== Honors == On 7 November 2010, Ilham Aliyev, the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan, signed an order on awarding Farid Aliyev with the title of "For heroism" Medal. According to the Decree, he was awarded the medal for his bravery while performing his military service in a very dangerous situation.<ref name="standard"/>
== Memorial == A documentary about Ahmedov’s personal life and military career was released in January 2014.<ref name="standard">{{cite web |url=http://modern.az/articles/50700/1/#gsc.tab=0 |title= Şəhid zabit Fərid Əhmədovla bağlı filmin təqdimatı oldu|last=|first=|date= 21 January 2014 |website=Modern.az|publisher=|access-date= 30 October 2018 |quote=}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Mubariz Ibrahimov]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Higher-order theories of consciousness''' postulate that [[consciousness]] consists in [[perceptions]] or thoughts about first-order [[mental states]].<ref name=Carruthers2011>{{cite web|author1=Peter Carruthers|title=Higher-Order Theories of Consciousness|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consciousness-higher/|website=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|accessdate=31 August 2014|date=15 Aug 2011}}</ref><ref name=RosenthalWeisberg2008>{{cite journal|author1=David Rosenthal|author2=Josh Weisberg|title=Higher-order theories of consciousness|journal=Scholarpedia|date=2008|volume=3|issue=5|page=4407 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.4407}}</ref><ref name=Droege>{{cite web|last1=Droege|first1=Paula|title=Higher-Order Theories of Consciousness|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/consc-hi/|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref> In particular, [[phenomenal consciousness]] is thought to be higher-order [[Mental representation|representation]] of perceptual or quasi-perceptual contents, such as visual images.<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
Higher-order theories are distinguished from other [[Cognition|cognitive]]/representational accounts of consciousness which suggest that merely first-order mentality of certain sorts constitutes consciousness.<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
==Motivation==
Higher-order theory can account for the distinction between unconscious and conscious brain processing. Both types of mental operations involve first-order manipulations, and according to higher-order theory, what makes cognition conscious is a higher-order observation of the first-order processing.<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
In [[neuroscience]] terms, higher-order theory is motivated by the distinction between first-order information in early sensory regions versus higher-order representations in [[Prefrontal cortex|prefrontal]] and [[Parietal lobe|parietal cortices]].<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|365–66}}
==Types==
===Higher-order perception theory===
Also called '''inner-sense theory''', this version of higher-order theory proposes that phenomenal consciousness consists not in immediate sensations but in higher-level sensing of those [[Sensation (psychology)|sensations]]. Or put another way: : A phenomenally conscious mental state is a state with analog/non-conceptual [[Intentionality|intentional]] content, which is in turn the target of a higher-order analog/non-conceptual intentional state, via the operations of a faculty of 'inner sense'.<ref name=Carruthers2011 /> One motivation for this approach is that it accounts for phenomenal consciousness absent beliefs or behaviors associated with those experiences—so that, e.g., someone could feel pain without necessarily exhibiting functional reactions to pain.<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
===Actualist higher-order thought theory===
[[David M. Rosenthal (philosopher)|David Rosenthal]] is a foremost advocate of this view. It claims that a mental state is conscious when it's the subject of a '''higher-order thought''' (HOT). Phenomenal consciousness in particular corresponds to certain kinds of mental states (e.g., visual inputs) that are the subjects of HOTs. Rosenthal excludes the special case in which one learns about one's lower-order states by conscious deduction. For instance, if [[psychoanalysis]] could reveal one's unconscious motives, this would not suddenly make them conscious.<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
===Dispositionalist higher-order thought theory===
The dispositionalist mirrors the actualist view except that the first-order mental state needn't actually be thought about—it only needs to be available to potentially be thought about.<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
While actualist accounts would seem to require immense higher-order computation on all first-order percepts, dispositionalist accounts do not; they merely require ''availability'' of first-order information. Such availability could come from, e.g., global broadcasting as in the [[Global Workspace Theory]].<ref name=Carruthers2011 />
===Self-representational higher-order theories===
Self-representational higher-order theories consider the higher-order state to be ''constitutive'' or ''internal'' to its first-order state.<ref name=Carruthers2011 /> This may be either because # the first-order and higher-order states are identical, with the same state serving two different roles, or # the first-order and higher-order states are part of the same whole, and the whole complex is what becomes conscious.<ref name=Carruthers2011 /> An example of the second, "part-whole" self-representational theory is Vincent Picciuto's "quotational theory of consciousness" in which consciousness consists of "mentally quoting" a first-order perception.<ref name=Picciuto2013>{{cite web|last1=Picciuto|first1=Vincent|title=Consciousness and Mental Quotation: An intrinsic higher-order approach|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1903/15231|website=Digital Repository at the University of Maryland|accessdate=31 August 2014|year=2013}}</ref>
===Higher-order statistical inference view===
In this theory, higher-level processing determines that a first-order representation is reliable.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|366}}
===Radical plasticity thesis===
Similar to a HOT view, this theory proposes that the brain "learns" when there exists a trustworthy lower-level representation.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|366}}
==Scientific perspectives==
Higher-order theories originated in philosophy, but they have also gained some scientific defenders.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011>{{cite journal|author1=Hakwan Lau|author2=David Rosenthal|title=Empirical support for higher-order theories of conscious awareness|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|date=Aug 2011|volume=15|issue=8|pages=365–373|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2011.05.009|url=http://www.summer12.isc.uqam.ca/page/docs/readings/Lau-Hakwan/Lau-Rosenthal-Empirical-support-for-higher-order-theories-of-conscious-awareness.pdf|pmid=21737339}}</ref>{{rp|365}} Here are some examples of evidence supporting higher-order views: * Reporting of conscious experience seems in some studies to occur serially following unconscious processing rather than in parallel with it.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|368}} * Unconscious processing is quite powerful on its own, so it's not obvious that task performance requires consciousness. Higher-order views agree with this, unlike, e.g., global-workspace views.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|368}} * Impairments to the prefrontal cortex may impair subjective reports without affecting task performance. If the prefrontal cortex were mainly serving an attentional role, performance should degrade along with reportability.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|369}} * Some interpretations of certain disorders of consciousness suggest that they operate by affecting the prefrontal cortex, where higher-order thoughts are assumed to take place.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|370–71}}
[[Edmund Rolls]] defends a higher-order account of consciousness. He argues that consciousness consists in higher-order thoughts allowing one to monitor and correct errors and "that the brain systems that are required for consciousness and language are similar."<ref name=Rolls2005>{{cite book|author1=Edmund T. Rolls|title=Emotion Explained|date=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0198570035}}</ref>{{rp|404–05}} [[Qualia]] like pain become conscious when "they enter into a specialized linguistic symbol-manipulation system, which is part of a higher-order thought system" that helps with, inter alia, "flexible planning of actions."<ref name=Rolls2005 />{{rp|407}}
==Criticisms==
===Against inner-sense and actualist HOT views===
Scott Sturgeon argues against inner-sense theory on the grounds that it could give rise to disorders in which, e.g., one has a first-order perception of red which mis-triggers a second-order sense of "looks orange". But we don't see any such disorders in [[neurology]].<ref name=Carruthers2011 /><ref name=Sturgeon2000>{{cite book|last1=Sturgeon|first1=Scott|title=Matters of Mind: Consciousness, Reason and Nature|date=2000|publisher=Routledge|location=London}}</ref> More generally, inner-sense and actualist views face the "targetless higher-order representation problem" in which there might be, e.g., a higher-order experience/thought about perceiving red without a corresponding first-order redness percept.<ref name=Carruthers2011 /> One reply is that this is no more a problem for higher-order theories than for other neuroscientific theories of consciousness, which also involve many layers of processing that could theoretically be inconsistent.<ref name=LauRosenthal2011 />{{rp|370}}
[[Peter Carruthers (philosopher)|Peter Carruthers]] points out that inner sense of or actualist HOTs about first-order percepts might greatly increase the computing power required to consciously process stimuli, for not only does one need to have a perception, but one then needs to have another (perhaps highly detailed) perception or thought about that perception.<ref name=Carruthers2011 /><ref name=Carruthers2000>{{cite book|last1=Carruthers|first1=Peter|title=Phenomenal Consciousness: A Naturalistic Theory|date=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge}}</ref>
===Against any higher-order view===
The "rock objection" notes that thinking about a rock doesn't cause the rock to "light up" with consciousness, so why does thinking about a first-order percept cause it to light up? Higher-order theorists reply that first-order states need to be mental states, which rocks are not.
==References== <references/>
{{philosophy of mind}}
[[Category:Philosophy of mind]] [[Category:Consciousness studies]] [[Category:Theory of mind]] [[Category:Consciousness]]

revision.text:
'''Industrial forensics''' is a holistic-based analytical and consultative response to problems encountered at any stage in the industrial [[manufacturing process]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.intertek.com/forensics/industrial/|title=Industrial Forensic Science|accessdate=February 29, 2012}}</ref> It differs from a traditional analytical approach that routinely identifies a problem and then reports the data in that its goal is to understand the problem, interpret the data and use those elements to prevent the problem from recurring. It is both [[prognostic]] and [[diagnostic]]. In its broadest sense, it is a holistic approach that examines each step in the product life cycle from initial R&D through final product and beyond to predict, identify, prevent and resolve manufacturing issues.
== Independent industrial forensics laboratory ==
A professional services laboratory that practices industrial forensics is an extension of the client's scientific organization.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mcl-inc.com/services/industrial-forensics/|title=Forensics - Materials & Chemistry Laboratory, Inc.|accessdate=February 29, 2012}}</ref> It identifies with the client's process and collaborates in the three areas that encompass all of the steps in the product life cycle: research and development (R&D), [[environmental health]] and safety (EH&S) and [[quality control]] (QA/QC).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rjlg.com/industrial-forensics-services.aspx|title=Industrial Forensics Services - RJ Lee Group|accessdate=February 29, 2012}}</ref> By examining each step in the manufacturing process in light of one or more of these areas, the laboratory obtains the data it needs to support the manufacturer's materials, processes and product before development, during the process and in the final product.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://factoidz.com/basic-steps-in-manufacturing-processes/|title=Basic Steps in Manufacturing Processes|accessdate=February 29, 2012}}</ref> The industrial forensic laboratory uses all available resources including bridging non-traditional expertise and technology and using standard approved methods as well as defining new procedures.
=== Research and development (R&D) ===
An industrial forensics laboratory works either as an R&D partner or an independent contractor selected for specific expertise. When working as an industrial partner, the laboratory becomes involved at the earliest stage of product development offering advice on raw materials selection and specifications. In the role of an outside expert, laboratory personnel and resources are made available to supplement the client's in-house capabilities. As an integral part of the R&D service provided, an industrial forensics laboratory is capable of determining [[root cause]] of [[Failure_analysis|failure]] at any step of the process in industries that range from [[nanotechnology]] to steel manufacturing.
=== Environmental health and safety (EH&S) ===
An industrial forensics laboratory assists industry in interpreting and applying government guidelines and regulations throughout the manufacturing process. The laboratory recommends measures needed to handle environmental concerns to both workers and product. The laboratory can also determine sources of pollutants during the manufacturing process that may affect the working environment and can design sampling and collection plans to monitor that process.
=== Quality assessment and quality control (QA/QC) ===
The industrial forensics laboratory works with the manufacturer to proactively address quality issues during the manufacturing process as well as post-production issues related to [[product recall]], warranty claims or [[product liability]]. The laboratory has the resources to provide litigation support.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.chemeca2011.com/abstract/468.asp * http://www.bu.edu/law/central/jd/organizations/journals/scitech/volume122/documents/Dubiansky_WEB_000.pdf * http://www.rdmag.com/Featured-Articles/2009/12/Policy-And-Industry-Global-Funding-Report-A-Battelle-Perspective-On-Innovation/ * http://biopharminternational.findpharma.com/biopharm/Quality/GMP-Issues-Moving-QA-onto-the-Manufacturing-Floor/ArticleStandard/Article/detail/75017 * http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iri/rtm/2007/00000050/00000001/art00006 * http://www.dfma.com/truecost/paper.pdf * http://blackerbyassoc.com/Overseas.html * http://www.rdmag.com/articles/2011/06/rising-phoenix
[[Category:Quality management]]

revision.text:
The '''International Violence Against Women Act of 2015''' ('''I-VAWA''') is proposed legislation to address [[violence against women]] through [[United States]] foreign policy. The legislation was introduced in the [[114th United States Congress]] in March, 2015. Similar legislation was introduced in the [[110th United States Congress|110th]] and [[111th United States Congress]] but was not passed into law.
==Background== At least 1 in 3 women around the world are subject to [[sexual abuse|sexual]], [[physical abuse|physical]] or other [[abuse]] during their life, per estimates by the [[United Nations Development Fund for Women]]. Not only does violence against women prevent mothers from raising healthy children, it also affects the economic progress and stability within the country in which they live.<ref name=AI-IssueBrief>[http://www.amnestyusa.org/sites/default/files/pdfs/ivawa_ib2.pdf ''The International Violence Against Women Act (I-VAWA) (S.2982, HR. 4594)''.] [[Amnesty International]] Issue Brief No. 2. March 2010. Retrieved November 23, 2011.</ref>
==International Violence Against Women Act of 2015== The International Violence Against Women Act of 2015 (I-VAWA) (S.713, HR. 1340) was introduced to ensure that addressing violence against women is included in the nation's foreign policy, with best practices for preventing violence, protecting victims and prosecuting offenders.<ref name=AI-IssueBrief/>
The legislation was the result of efforts by: * [[Amnesty International USA]] * [[Family Violence Prevention Fund]] * [[Women Thrive Worldwide]].<ref name=AI-IssueBrief/>
Experts in related fields from 40 international and 150 U.S. groups provided input for the legislation.<ref name=AI-IssueBrief/>
The House of Representatives Bill (HR. 1340) was brought before the [[114th_United_States_Congress|114th Congress]], sponsored by Representative [[Jan_Schakowsky|Janice Schakowsky]], [[Illinois's 9th congressional district]]. The Senate Bill (S.713), was introduced by Senator [[Barbara Boxer]] of [[California]].
==Criticism== I-VAWA has been criticized on the grounds that it would discriminate against male victims and impose Western values upon other societies. According to [[Wendy McElroy]], a research fellow at [[The Independent Institute]], the Act "constitutes a 5-year redirection of foreign aid funds in order to insert politically-correct feminism into the structure of other nations" and "revictimizes every male victim by denying his existence."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/civil-rights/197947-i-vawas-global-lie|last=McElroy|first=Wendy|title=I-VAWA's global lie|journal=The Hill|date=February 11, 2014}}</ref>
==Organizations== Many organizations support the I-VAWA Act, some of which are: * [[Amnesty International USA]] * [[American Jewish World Service]] * [[Human Rights Watch]] * [[International Center for Research on Women]] * [[International Rescue Committee]] * [[Refugees International]] * [[Vital Voices]] * [[Women's Refugee Commission]]<ref>[http://www.womenthrive.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=436&Itemid=152 ''International Violence Against Women Act Organizational Supporters.''] Women Thrive Worldwide. Retrieved November 23, 2011.</ref>
==See also== *[[Child Protective Services]] *[[Domestic violence]] *[[Futures Without Violence]] *[[Rape culture]] *[[Relationship education]] *[[Violence Against Women Act]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Domestic violence]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]] [[Category:Proposed laws of the United States]]
