page.title: List of victims of the Babi Yar massacre

revision.comment: /* See also */
/* Criminally negligent manslaughter */
revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{homicide}} {{Criminal law}} '''Manslaughter''' is a [[common law]] legal term for [[homicide]] considered by law as less [[Culpability|culpable]] than [[murder]]. The distinction between murder and manslaughter is sometimes said to have first been made by the ancient Athenian lawmaker [[Draco (lawgiver)|Draco]] in the 7th century BC.{{cite book |last=Ehrenberg |first=Victor |authorlink=Victor Ehrenberg (historian) |title=From Solon to Socrates: Greek History and Civilization During the 6th and 5th Centuries BC |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9V2hAwAAQBAJ |accessdate=31 December 2015 |edition=Second |year=1973 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn=978-0-415-04024-2 |page=57 |orig-year=1968}} The definition of manslaughter differs among legal [[jurisdiction (area)|jurisdictions]]. ==General== ===Voluntary manslaughter=== {{main article|Voluntary manslaughter}} In voluntary manslaughter, the offender had no prior intent to kill and acted "in the moment" under circumstances that could cause a reasonable person to become emotionally or mentally disturbed. Examples could include a defender killing a home invader without being placed in a life or death situation.{{cite journal|last1=Weber|first1=Jack K.|title=Some Provoking Aspects of Voluntary Manslaughter Law|journal=Anglo-American Law Review|date=1 July 1981|volume=10|page=159|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/147377958101000302?journalCode=clwa|accessdate=10 September 2017}} There are mitigating circumstances that reduce culpability, such as when the defendant kills only with an intent to cause serious bodily harm.{{cite book|last1=Allen|first1=Michael|title=Textbook on Criminal Law|date=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, U.K.|isbn=9780199669295|edition=12|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VaScAQAAQBAJ|accessdate=10 September 2017}} Voluntary manslaughter in some jurisdictions is a [[lesser included offense]] of murder. The traditional mitigating factor was [[provocation (legal)|provocation]]; however, others have been added in various jurisdictions. The most common type of voluntary manslaughter occurs when a defendant is provoked to commit homicide. This is sometimes described as a [[crime of passion]].{{cite journal|last1=Dressler|first1=Joshua|title=Rethinking heat of passion: A defense in search of a rationale|journal=Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology|date=Summer 1982|volume=73|issue=2|page=421|url=http://scholarlycommons.law.northwestern.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=6302&context=jclc|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024403/http://scholarlycommons.law.northwestern.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=6302&context=jclc|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} In most cases, the provocation must induce rage or anger in the defendant, although some cases have held that fright, terror, or desperation will suffice.{{cite book|last1=Barkan|first1=Steven E.|last2=Bryjak|first2=George J.|title=Myths and Realities of Crime and Justice: What Every American Should Know|date=2009|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Publishers|location=Massachusetts|isbn=9780763755744|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GNIWv8-WfAEC|accessdate=10 September 2017}} ====Assisted suicide==== {{Main article|Assisted suicide}} Assisted suicide is suicide committed with the aid of another person, sometimes a physician. In some places, including parts of the United States,{{cite web|title=Patients Rights Council|url=http://www.patientsrightscouncil.org/site/assisted-suicide-state-laws/|website=Assisted Suicide Laws in the United States|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=6 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911025119/http://www.patientsrightscouncil.org/site/assisted-suicide-state-laws/|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} [[assisted suicide]] is punishable as manslaughter. In other countries such as Switzerland{{cite news|last1=Sarchet|first1=Penny|title=Tourism to Switzerland for assisted suicide is growing, often for nonfatal diseases|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/tourism-to-switzerland-for-assisted-suicide-is-growing-often-for-nonfatal-diseases/2014/09/22/3b9de644-2a14-11e4-958c-268a320a60ce_story.html|accessdate=10 September 2017|publisher=Washington Post|date=22 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911031138/https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/tourism-to-switzerland-for-assisted-suicide-is-growing-often-for-nonfatal-diseases/2014/09/22/3b9de644-2a14-11e4-958c-268a320a60ce_story.html|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} and Canada,{{cite web|title=Assisted Suicide|url=http://eol.law.dal.ca/?page_id=236|website=End of Life Law & Policy in Canada|publisher=Health Law Institute, Dalhousie University|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024543/http://eol.law.dal.ca/?page_id=236|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} and in some U.S. states, as long as legal safeguards are observed, assisted suicide is legal. ===Involuntary manslaughter=== ''Involuntary manslaughter'' is the homicide of a human being without intent of doing so, either expressed or implied. It is distinguished from voluntary manslaughter by the absence of intention. It is normally divided into two categories, constructive manslaughter and criminally negligent manslaughter, both of which involve criminal liability. ====Constructive manslaughter==== Constructive manslaughter is also referred to as "unlawful act" manslaughter. It is based on the doctrine of constructive malice, whereby the malicious intent inherent in the commission of a crime is considered to apply to the consequences of that crime. It occurs when someone kills, without intent, in the course of committing an unlawful act. The malice involved in the crime is transferred to the killing, resulting in a charge of manslaughter. For example, a person who fails to stop at a red traffic light while driving a vehicle and hits someone crossing the street could be found to intend or be reckless as to assault or criminal damage (see ''DPP v Newbury''[1977] AC 500). There is no intent to kill, and a resulting death would not be considered murder, but would be considered involuntary manslaughter. The accused's responsibility for causing death is constructed from the fault in committing what might have been a minor criminal act. Reckless driving or reckless handling of a potentially lethal weapon may result in a death that is deemed manslaughter. Involuntary manslaughter may be distinguished from accidental death. A person who is driving carefully, but whose car nevertheless hits a child darting out into the street, has not committed manslaughter. A person who pushes off an aggressive drunk, who then falls and dies, has probably not committed manslaughter, although in some jurisdictions it may depend whether "excessive force" was used or other factors. As manslaughter is not defined by legislation in Australia, common law decisions provide the basis for determining whether an act resulting in death amounts to manslaughter by unlawful and dangerous act.{{cite AustLII|NSWCCA|317|2013|litigants=Lane v R |pinpoint=[46] |courtname=auto |date-}}. To be found guilty of manslaughter by an unlawful and dangerous act, the accused must be shown to have committed an unlawful act which is contrary to the criminal law,{{cite AustLII|HCA|31|1992|litigants=Wilson v R |parallelcite=(1992) 174 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 313 per Brennan, Deane and Dawson JJ at [2] |courtname=auto |date=}}. and that a reasonable person in the position of the accused would have known that by their act, they were exposing the victim to an ‘appreciable risk of serious injury’.{{cite AustLII|HCA|31|1992|litigants=Wilson v R |parallelcite=(1992) 174 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 313 per Mason CJ, Toohey, Gaudron and McHugh JJ at [48] |courtname=auto |date=}}. ====Criminally negligent manslaughter==== Criminally negligent manslaughter is variously referred to as [[criminally negligent]] homicide in the [[United States]], and [[gross negligence]] manslaughter in [[England and Wales]]. In [[Scotland]] and some [[Commonwealth of Nations]] jurisdictions the offence of [[culpable homicide]] might apply. It occurs where death results from serious [[criminal negligence|negligence]], or, in some jurisdictions, serious [[Recklessness (law)|recklessness]]. A high degree of negligence is required to warrant criminal liability. A related concept is that of [[willful blindness]], which is where a defendant intentionally puts themself in a position where the defendant will be unaware of facts which would render them liable. Criminally negligent manslaughter occurs where there is an omission to act when there is a duty to do so, or a failure to perform a duty owed, which leads to a death. The existence of the duty is essential because the law does not impose criminal liability for a failure to act unless a specific duty is owed to the victim. It is most common in the case of professionals who are grossly negligent in the course of their employment. An example is where a doctor fails to notice a patient's oxygen supply has disconnected and the patient dies (''R v Adomako'').{{cite BAILII|court=UKHL |year=1994 |num=6 |litigants=R v Adomako |parallelcite=[1994] 3 [[Weekly Law Reports|WLR]] 288 |courtname=auto}}. Another example could be leaving a child locked in a car on a hot day.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} ====Vehicular or intoxication manslaughter==== In some jurisdictions, such as some U.S. States,See, e.g., {{cite web|title=New York Penal Code, Sec. 125.13. Vehicular manslaughter in the first degree.|url=https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/laws/PEN/125.13|website=New York State Senate|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911025304/https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/laws/PEN/125.13|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}}See also {{cite web|title=California Penal Code, Sec. 192(c)|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=PEN§ionNum=192.|website=California Legislative Information|publisher=California Legislature|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912005131/https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=PEN§ionNum=192.|archivedate=12 September 2017|df=}}See also {{cite web|title=Wisconsin Statutes, Sec. 940.09. Homicide by intoxicated use of vehicle or firearm.|url=https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/statutes/statutes/940/I/09|website=Wisconsin State Legislature|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024628/https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/statutes/statutes/940/I/09|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}}See also {{cite web|title=Texas Penal Code, Sec. 49.08. Intoxication Manslaughter|url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/PE/htm/PE.49.htm#49.08|website=Texas State Legislature|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024145/http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/PE/htm/PE.49.htm#49.08|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} there exists the specific crime of vehicular or [[Substance intoxication|intoxication]] manslaughter. An equivalent in Canada is [[Criminal negligence#Canada|causing death by criminal negligence]]{{cite web|title=Criminal Code (R.S.C., 1985, c. C-46), Sec. 220, Causing Death by Criminal Negligence|url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-220.html|website=Justice Laws Website|publisher=Government of Canada|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911025403/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-220.html|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} under the [[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]], punishable by a maximum penalty of [[Life imprisonment in Canada|life imprisonment]]. ==Regional differences== The definition of manslaughter differs from one [[jurisdiction (area)|jurisdiction]] to another. The law generally differentiates between levels of criminal culpability based on the ''[[mens rea]]'', or state of mind, or the circumstances under which the killing occurred ([[mitigating factor]]s). Manslaughter is usually broken down into two distinct categories: ''[[#Voluntary manslaughter|voluntary manslaughter]]'' and ''[[#Involuntary manslaughter|involuntary manslaughter]]''.{{cite web|title=Manslaughter|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/manslaughter|website=Wex|publisher=Cornell Law School|accessdate=29 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911025453/https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/manslaughter|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} However, this is not the case in all jurisdictions, for example, in the U.S. state of Florida.{{cite web|title=Florida Statutes, Sec. 782.07. Manslaughter|url=http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&URL=0700-0799/0782/Sections/0782.07.html|website=Online Sunshine|publisher=State of Florida|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024521/http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&URL=0700-0799%2F0782%2FSections%2F0782.07.html|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} In some jurisdictions,{{cite web|last1=Berman|first1=Mitchell N.|title=Provocation as a Partial Justification and Partial Excuse|url=http://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2492&context=faculty_scholarship|website=Penn Law: Legal Scholarship Repository|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Law School|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416094652/http://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2492&context=faculty_scholarship|archivedate=16 April 2016|df=}} such as the U.K.,{{cite web|title=Loss Of Control And Diminished Responsibility|url=https://www.oxbridgenotes.co.uk/revision_notes/gdl-law-gdl-criminal-law/samples/loss-of-control-and-diminished-responsibility|website=Oxbridge Notes|accessdate=10 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024914/https://www.oxbridgenotes.co.uk/revision_notes/gdl-law-gdl-criminal-law/samples/loss-of-control-and-diminished-responsibility|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}} Canada,{{cite web|last1=Knoll|first1=Pat|title=CED, an Overview of the Law — Criminal Law – Defences: Provocation|url=http://www.westlawnextcanada.com/blog/insider/ced-an-overview-of-the-law-criminal-law-defences-provocation-363/|website=WestLaw Next Canada|publisher=Thomson Reuters|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=14 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911024723/http://www.westlawnextcanada.com/blog/insider/ced-an-overview-of-the-law-criminal-law-defences-provocation-363/|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}}{{cite news|last1=Fine|first1=Sean|title=Supreme Court dismisses ‘provoked’ defence claim in murder cases|url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/supreme-court-denies-provocation-defence-in-edmonton-murder-case/article15074110/|accessdate=10 September 2017|publisher=Globe and Mail|date=25 October 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180605033619/https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/supreme-court-denies-provocation-defence-in-edmonton-murder-case/article15074110/|archivedate=5 June 2018|df=}} and some Australian states,{{cite web|title=Provocation as a Defence to Murder|url=https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/Digitization/62008NCJRS.pdf|website=National Criminal Justice Reference Service|publisher=Government of Australia|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=1979|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216121725/https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/Digitization/62008NCJRS.pdf|archivedate=16 February 2017|df=}} [[Provocation (legal)|"adequate provocation"]] may be a partial defense to a charge of murder, which, if accepted by the jury, would convert what might otherwise have been a murder charge into manslaughter. ===Australian law=== In Australia, specifically New South Wales, manslaughter is referred to, however not defined, in the ''Crimes Act 1900'' (NSW).{{cite Legislation AU|NSW|act|ca190082|Crimes Act 1900|18}} Murder and manslaughter defined. Manslaughter exists in two forms in New South Wales: Voluntary or Involuntary Manslaughter. In New South Wales, in cases of voluntary manslaughter, both the ''[[actus reus]]'' (literally [[wiktionary:actus reus|guilty act]]) and ''[[mens rea]]'' (literally [[wiktionary:mens rea|guilty mind]]) for murder are proven but the defendant has a partial defence, such as extreme provocation or diminished responsibility.{{cite Legislation AU|NSW|act|ca190082|Crimes Act 1900|23}} and {{cite Legislation AU|NSW|act|ca190082/23a.html|23A}}.{{rp|[51]–[65]}} In cases of involuntary manslaughter, the ''actus reus'' for murder is present but there is insufficient ''mens rea'' to establish such a charge. There are two categories of involuntary manslaughter at common law: manslaughter by unlawful and dangerous act and manslaughter by criminal negligence. The authority for the ''actus reus'' and ''mens rea'' of involuntary manslaughter by an unlawful and dangerous act is the High Court of Australia case of ''Wilson v R''.{{cite AustLII|HCA|31|1992|litigants=Wilson v R |parallelcite=(1992) 174 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 313 |courtname=auto |date=}}. This case determined that the act that caused the death must breach the criminal law and that the act must carry an appreciable risk of serious injury (''actus reus''). Regarding the ''mens rea'', the court held that the accused must intend to commit the unlawful act and that a reasonable person in the position of the accused would have realised or recognised that the act carried an appreciable risk of serious injury. Manslaughter by criminal negligence, on the other hand, finds its authority in the Victorian case of ''Nydam v R'',{{cite AustLII|VicRp|50|1977|litigants=Nydam v R |parallelcite=[1977] [[Victorian Reports|VR]] 430 |courtname=auto |date=17 December 1976}}. confirmed by the High Court of Australia in ''[[R v Lavender]]''{{cite AustLII|HCA|37|2005|litigants=[[R v Lavender]] |parallelcite=(2005) 222 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 67 at [17], [60], [72], [136] |courtname=auto |date=4 August 2005}}. and ''Burns v R''.{{cite AustLII|HCA|35|2012|litigants=Burns v R |parallelcite=(2012) 246 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 334 per French CJ at [19] |courtname=auto |date=14 September 2012}}. In ''Nydam v R'', the Court described the office at [445] in the following terms:
In order to establish manslaughter by criminal negligence, it is sufficient if the prosecution shows that the act which caused the death was done by the accused consciously and voluntarily, without any intention of causing death or grievous bodily harm but in circumstances which involved such a great falling short of the standard of care which a reasonable man would have exercised and which involved such a high risk that death or grievous bodily harm would follow that the doing of the act merited criminal punishment.
===Canadian law=== Canadian law distinguishes between justifiable, accidental and culpable homicide. If a death is deemed a culpable homicide, it generally falls under one of four categories (first-degree murder, second-degree murder, manslaughter, and infanticide). Canadian law defines manslaughter as "a homicide committed without the intention to cause death, although there may have been an intention to cause harm". There are two broad categories of manslaughter: unlawful act, and criminal negligence. Unlawful act is when a person commits a crime that unintentionally results in the death of another person. Criminal negligence is when the homicide was the result of an act that showed wanton or reckless disregard for the lives of others.{{cite web|title=Murder vs. Manslaughter|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/murder-vs-manslaughter-1.1155132|website=CBC News|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=27 February 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912233043/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/murder-vs-manslaughter-1.1155132|archivedate=12 September 2017|df=}} ===English law=== {{Main article|Manslaughter in English law}} In [[English law]], manslaughter is a less serious offence than [[murder in English law|murder]]. In [[England and Wales]], the usual practice is to prefer a charge of murder, with the [[judge]] or defence able to introduce manslaughter as an option (see [[lesser included offence]]). The [[jury]] then decides whether the [[defendant]] is guilty or not guilty of either murder or manslaughter. Manslaughter may be either voluntary or involuntary, depending on whether the accused has the required ''mens rea'' for murder. The [[Homicide Act 1957]] and [[Coroners and Justice Act 2009]] are relevant acts. Voluntary manslaughter occurs when the defendant avails themself of the three statutory defenses described in the Homicide Act 1957 (provocation, diminished responsibility, and a suicide pact). Involuntary manslaughter occurs when the agent has no intention (mens rea) of committing murder, but caused the death of another through [[recklessness (law)|recklessness]] or [[criminal negligence]]. The crime of involuntary manslaughter can be subdivided into two main categories: constructive manslaughter and gross negligence manslaughter. ===United States law=== {{Main article|Manslaughter (United States law)}} Manslaughter is a crime in the [[United States]]. Definitions can vary among jurisdictions, but the U.S. follows the general principle that manslaughter involves causing the death of another person in a manner less [[culpable]] than [[murder]], and observes the distinction between voluntary and involuntary manslaughter.{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=What Are Homicide and Murder|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/criminal-law/what-are-homicide-and-murder|website=ExpertLaw.com|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=17 October 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910041250/https://www.expertlaw.com/library/criminal-law/what-are-homicide-and-murder|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} ===Civil Law=== [[Civil law (legal system)|Civil Law]] jurisdictions, such as the [[Code pénal (France)|French Code]], use "murder" or "involuntary homicide" to cover the crime of manslaughter, and reserve "assassination" for the crime of [[premeditated murder]].{{cite web |title=Criminal Code of the French Republic |date=2005 |url=http://www.legislationline.org/documents/section/criminal-codes/country/30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180205072708/http://www.legislationline.org/documents/section/criminal-codes/country/30 |archivedate=2018-02-05 |df= }} ==See also== * [[Culpable homicide]] * [[Criminal transmission of HIV]] * [[Depraved-heart murder]] * [[Imperfect self-defense]] * [[Twinkie defense]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|manslaughter}} {{Wikiversity}} [[Category:Manslaughter| ]] [[Category:Homicide]] [[Category:Criminal law]]

revision.comment: /* Early life */Added further content about the early life trauma that Mary Bell experienced , which turned her into the killer she is.
revision.text:
{{Other people|Mary Bell}} {{Use British English|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Mary Bell | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1957|5|26}} | birth_place = [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], Northumberland<!-- Please note: Tyne and Wear did not exist until 1974-->, England | death_date = | death_place = | alias = The Tyneside Strangler | conviction = [[Manslaughter in English law|Manslaughter]] | penalty = 12 years imprisonment | status = Released | occupation = | spouse = | parents = Betty McCrickett | children = 1 | date = 1968 | fatalities = 2 }} '''Mary Flora Bell''' (born 26 May 1957) is an English woman who, as a child aged 10–11 in 1968, strangled to death two young boys in [[Scotswood]], an inner-city suburb in the West End district of [[Newcastle upon Tyne]]. She was convicted in December 1968 of the [[manslaughter]] of Martin Brown (aged 4) and Brian Howe (aged 3).<ref name="BBCNews1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/17/newsid_3261000/3261087.stm|title=17 December: 1968: Mary Bell found guilty of double killing|work=BBC On This Day|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=12 May 2010|date=17 December 1968}}</ref>
Since her release from prison in 1980, she has lived under a series of pseudonyms. Her identity has been protected by a court order, which has also been extended to protect the identity of her daughter. In 1998, Bell collaborated with [[Gitta Sereny]] on an account of her life, in which she details the abuse she suffered as a child at the hands of her mother{{snd}}a prostitute{{snd}}and her mother's clients. ==Early life== Bell's mother Betty (née McCrickett) was a prostitute who was often absent from the family home, travelling to [[Glasgow]] to work. Mary (nicknamed May)<ref name="BBCNews1"/> was her first child, born when Betty was 17 years old. It is not known who Mary's biological father was. For most of her life she believed it to be Billy Bell, a habitual criminal who was later arrested for armed robbery, but Bell married McCrickett when Mary was a baby.<ref name="Cries1"/>
Independent accounts from family members strongly suggest that Betty had more than once attempted to kill Mary and make her death look accidental during the first few years of her life. Her family was suspicious when Mary "fell" from a window, and when she "accidentally" consumed sleeping pills. On one such occasion, an independent witness saw Betty giving the pills to her daughter as sweets.<ref name="Cries1">{{cite book |last=Sereny |first=Gitta |title=Cries Unheard: the Story of Mary Bell |publisher=Macmillan |year=1998 |location=London |isbn=0-333-73524-2|pages=330–34}}</ref> Mary herself says she was subjected to repeated sexual abuse, her mother forcing her from the age of four to engage in sexual acts with men.<ref name="Cries Unheard2">{{cite book |last=Sereny |first=Gitta |title=Cries Unheard: the Story of Mary Bell |publisher=Macmillan |year=1998 |location=London|pages=334–36|isbn=0-333-73524-2}}</ref>
It was reported after this "fall" that Mary experienced, that she had suffered from brain damage. At the time this was reported as a result of the fall, however we now know this may be due to the abuse she has experienced as a child, from her own mother. Mary had damage to her prefrontal cortex, an are associated with voluntary movements and decision-making.<ref name="Cries Unheard2">{{cite book |last=Sereny |first=Gitta |title=Cries Unheard: the Story of Mary Bell |publisher=Macmillan |year=1998 |location=London|pages=334–36|isbn=0-333-73524-2}}</ref>
==Killings== On 25 May 1968, the day before her 11th birthday, Mary Bell strangled 4-year-old Martin Brown in a derelict house.<ref name="BBCNews1"/> She was believed to have committed this crime alone. Between that time and a second killing, she and a friend, '''Norma Joyce Bell''' (1955–1989; no relation), aged 13, broke into and vandalised a nursery in Scotswood, leaving notes that claimed responsibility for the killing. The police dismissed this incident as a prank.<ref>''The Case of Mary Bell: A Portrait of a Child Who Murdered'', page 115, Gitta Sereny, 1972</ref>
On 31 July 1968, the two girls took part in the death, again by strangulation, of 3-year-old Brian Howe, in a wasteland in the same Scotswood area.<ref name="BBCNews1"/> Police reports concluded that Mary Bell had later returned to his body to carve an "M" into the boy's stomach. Mary Bell also used a pair of scissors to cut off some of Howe's hair, scratch his legs, and mutilate his penis.<ref>''The Case Of Mary Bell: A Portrait of a Child Who Murdered''</ref>
==Conviction and imprisonment== On 17 December 1968, at Newcastle [[Assizes]], Norma Bell was acquitted but Mary Bell was convicted of manslaughter on the grounds of [[Diminished responsibility in English law|diminished responsibility]], the jury taking their lead from her diagnosis by court-appointed psychiatrists who described her as displaying "classic symptoms of [[psychopathy]]". The judge, Justice Cusack, described her as dangerous and said she posed a "very grave risk to other children".<ref name="The Independent">{{cite news|last1=SMITH|first1=JOAN|title=For ever a child-killer|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/for-ever-a-child-killer-1161689.html|accessdate=27 October 2017|work=The Independent|publisher=Independent Digital News and Media Ltd.|date=3 May 1998}}</ref> She was sentenced to be detained [[at Her Majesty's pleasure]], effectively an indefinite sentence of imprisonment. She was initially sent to [[Red Bank secure unit]] in [[Newton-Le-Willows]], [[Lancashire]] – the same facility that would house Jon Venables, one of [[Murder of James Bulger|James Bulger]]'s killers, 25 years later.<ref name="BBCNews1"/><ref name="Owlcation">{{cite news|last1=Monacelli|first1=Antonia|title=Murderous Children: 11-Year-Old Serial Killer Mary Bell|url=https://owlcation.com/social-sciences/Murderous-Children-Mary-Bell|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=Owlcation|publisher=[[HubPages Inc.]]|date=23 May 2016|location=Scotswood, England|language=en|quote=Mary Bell, The Tyneside Strangler: "I Murder So That I May Come Back"}}</ref>
After her conviction, Bell was the focus of a great deal of attention from the British press and also from the German magazine ''[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]''. Her mother repeatedly sold stories about her to the press and often gave reporters writings she claimed to be by her daughter. Bell herself made headlines when, in September 1977, she briefly escaped from Moor Court [[open prison]], where she had been held since her transfer from a [[Her Majesty's Young Offender Institution|young offenders institution]] to an adult prison a year earlier.<ref name="The Telegraph">{{cite news|last1=Fraser|first1=Lorraine|last2=Alderson|first2=Andrew|title=How a 'terrified' Mary Bell walked back into the world|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1312518/How-a-terrified-Mary-Bell-walked-back-into-the-world.html|accessdate=27 October 2017|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|date=24 June 2001|quote=Bell, who had briefly escaped from prison in 1977, was in Styal prison in Cheshire when the Parole Board decided that she should be freed.}}</ref> Her penalty for this was a loss of prison privileges for 28 days.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/millennium/1900/1976-2000/1977.html |title=Street parties for the Queen |work=Our Century |publisher=Express & Star}}</ref>
For a time, Bell also lived in a girls' remand home at Cumberlow Lodge in [[South Norwood]] (in a house built by Victorian inventor [[William Stanley (inventor)|William Stanley]]).<ref>{{cite book|last=Akpan|first=Eloïse|title=''The Story of William Stanley – A Self-made Man|publisher=Eloïse Akpan|location=London|year=2000|pages=40|isbn=0-9538577-0-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=074-lcc_4&cid=8-18#8-18 |title=Cumberlow lodge, approved school and remand home south Norwood; General LCC/CH/D/CUM/1 [n.d.] |publisher=The National Archives}}</ref>
==Life after prison== In 1980, Bell, aged 23, was released from [[Askham Grange]] open prison after having served 12 years and was granted anonymity (including a new name), allowing her to start a new life.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Short and Brutal Timeline|url=http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/crime-files/mary-bell/timeline|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=Crime + Investigation|publisher=AETN UK|date=29 June 2017|language=en|quote=1980 - Mary Bell is released from prison}}</ref> Four years later she had a daughter, born on 25 May 1984. Bell's daughter did not know of her mother's past until Bell's location was discovered by reporters in 1998 and she and her mother had to leave their house with bed sheets over their heads.
Bell's daughter's anonymity was originally protected only until she reached the age of 18. However, on 21 May 2003, Bell won a [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] battle to have her own anonymity and that of her daughter extended for life.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Early|first1=Chas|title=December 17, 1968: Britain in shock as Mary Bell, 11, is found guilty of toddler murders|url=http://home.bt.com/news/on-this-day/december-17-1968-11-year-old-mary-bell-found-guilty-of-killing-toddlers-11364029165478|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=BT.com|language=en}}</ref> Any court order permanently protecting the identity of a convict in Britain is consequently sometimes known as a "Mary Bell order".<ref name="Mirror">{{cite news|last1=Edwards|first1=Jeff|title=Shocked to the core: 10 crimes that shook Britain|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/10-crimes-that-shook-britain-817163|accessdate=27 October 2017|work=mirror|publisher=MGN Limited|date=6 May 2012|language=en|quote=... a plea to a court that her identity should not be revealed by the media was accepted by the High Court under what became known as the Mary Bell law.}}</ref>
==Books about the case== Bell is the subject of two books by [[Gitta Sereny]]: ''The Case of Mary Bell'' (1972), an account of the killings and trial, and ''Cries Unheard: the Story of Mary Bell'' (1998),<ref name="CBS News">{{cite news|title=Understanding The Root Of Evil|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/understanding-the-root-of-evil/|accessdate=27 October 2017|work=CBSNews.com staff|publisher=CBS Interactive|date=21 October 1999|language=en|quote=Sereny contends Mary used evil conduct as a cry to be rescued from a horrific childhood.}}</ref> an in-depth biography based on interviews with Bell and relatives, friends and professionals who knew her during and after her imprisonment.<ref name="Cries Unheard">{{cite book |last=Sereny |first=Gitta |title=Cries Unheard: the Story of Mary Bell |publisher=Macmillan |year=1998 |location=London |isbn=0-333-73524-2}}</ref> This second book was the first to detail Bell's account of sexual abuse at the hands of her mother, a prostitute who specialised as a [[dominatrix]], and her mother's clients.<ref name="NY Times">{{cite news|last1=KOTLOWITZ|first1=ALEX|title=A Bad Seed?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/04/18/reviews/990418.18kotlowt.html|accessdate=27 October 2017|work=www.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=18 April 1999|language=en|quote=... and that Betty, a prostitute, used her daughter as a sexual prop in some of her sadomasochistic encounters.}}</ref>
The publication of ''Cries Unheard'' was controversial because Bell received payment for her participation.<ref name="The Economist">{{cite news|title=The hounding of Mary Bell|url=http://www.economist.com/node/125568|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=The Economist|publisher=The Economist Newspaper Limited|date=30 April 1998|quote=Inflamed by the publication of a new book on the case—and by the fact that Miss Bell accepted a substantial sum of money from its author, Gitta Sereny—Britain's tabloids have eagerly pursued their new quarry}}</ref> The payment was criticised by the [[tabloid journalism|tabloid]] press, and [[Tony Blair]]'s government attempted to find a legal means to prevent its publication on the grounds that a criminal should not profit from his or her crimes, but the attempt was unsuccessful.
Bell is one of thirteen child killers reported on in the book ''Children Who Kill: Profiles of Pre-teen and Teenage Killers'' by author Carol Anne Davis, published in 2004.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Carol Anne Davis|title=Children who kill : Profiles of Pre-teen and Teenage Killers|date=2004|publisher=Allison & Busby|location=London|isbn=9780749006938|url=https://www.worldofbooks.com/children-who-kill-profiles-of-pre-teen-and-teenage-killers-by-carol-anne-davis-gor001318318.html|accessdate=26 October 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Murder of James Bulger]], the murder of a 2-year-old child committed by two ten-year-old boys in 1993 * [[Eric Smith (murderer)|Eric Smith]], who at the age of 13 killed a 4-year-old boy in 1993 * [[Edlington attacks]], the attempted murder of two boys by two other boys aged 10 and 11 in 2009 * [[Parker-Hulme murder case]], which was the basis for the [[Peter Jackson]] film ''[[Heavenly Creatures]]'' * [[Son of Sam law]], a law designed to keep criminals from profiting from the publicity of their crimes
{{Portalbar|United Kingdom|Criminal justice|Biography}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150209235802/http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/famous/bell/index_1.html Crime Library entry] *[http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/latenightlive/classic-lnl-the-story-of-mary-bell/3212804 Interview with Gitta Sereny, 1998] – with LNL's Phillip Adams
{{Authority control}}

#REDIRECT [[Funeral#Mutes and professional mourners]]
[[Category:Death customs]]

'''Operational continuity''' refers to the ability of a system to continue working despite damages, losses or critical events. In the Human Resources and Organizational domain, including IT, it implies the need to determine the level of [[Resilience_(organizational)|resilience]] of the system, its ability to recover after an event, and build a system that resists to external and internal events or is able to recover after an event without losing its external [[performance management]] capability. Organizational Continuity is achieved only with specific corporate planning.<ref>Argenti, John (1974). Systematic Corporate Planning. Wiley.</ref> In the material domain, it determines the need to adopt redundant systems, performance monitoring systems, and can even imply the practice to cannibalize or to remove serviceable assemblies, sub-assemblies or components from a repairable or serviceable item of equipment in order to install them on another, in order to keep the external system performance active.<ref>North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Nato Standardization Agency AAP-6 - Glossary of terms and definitions, p 188.</ref> Operational continuity may be referred to single systems, single individuals, up to teams or entire complex systems such as IT infrastructures, implying the ability of an organization or system to continue to provide its mission.
==See also== * [[Business continuity]] * [[Disaster response]] * [[Emergency management]]
